content:
Posted: September 3, 2015
												I would be wary of reviewers that invest 5 hours or less into this game. The Advanced Mode's machines, along with the Centrifuge from Intermediate, radically increase the ways in which you can manipulate ingredients. It's also much harder to make and maintain a large profit, especially since competitors play a much greater role in the Advanced Mode. You'll need to start utilizing some hidden optimization tricks involving things like the packer or crossing belts with machines that have a cycle time greater than 1. So while dead-simple machine placement will get you through the Beginner and some of the Intermediate Scenarios, reaching Master in the Advanced Scenarios requires a lot more thought.The negative reviews for this game have some merit, but the game doesn't promise anything more than it delivers. What this game does, it does very well: designing and optimizing production lines, anticipating what the market for a drug will bear, deciding what ingredients and machines to research or upgrade, all while balancing a budget that is very tight early and expands greatly over time. It's a beautifully-animated game that presents a relaxed puzzle atmosphere and gives you almost all of the information you'll need up-front.Let's get some things out of the way, though. Sick people are abstractions, which is honestly what I'd expect from most Pharmaceutical companies. The larger the market for a cure, the greater the relative price and the more of that cure you can produce without tanking the price. The market can increase or decrease as a result of random world events, increase naturally over time for infectious diseases, and decrease as people are cured. A cure that's particularly potent will fetch a much higher price, but you may eventually be left without a viable market for that product.The available cures and how they're upgraded are static. The starting concentration of an ingredient has a fairly narrow range based on the range of the Level 1 cure. The number of plots available for purchase, and the sockets within each building layout, are predetermined. On the other hand...The ingredient order is random, side effects are assigned semi-randomly, the building layouts you get are random, and the market for each cure is random within a small range. This can make or break the profitability of several cures, but the Level 1 cure of every starting ingredient is profitable and smart research choices can dig you out of some terrible early setups. Even a terrible cure can fetch a profit, although it can be much lower than you'd get from a perfect cure.Anyone who says that the Competitors are pointless was playing on one of the easier difficulties. The competition presents a real challenge in Advanced Mode, as you have 3 competitors that all have the same early options that you do. Different AI companies prioritize different things, but they'll usually go for the more profitable cures and cures that can fetch high ratings (ie, no side effects). You have to be smart with your market choices in Advanced because the AI will very quickly oversaturate and tank the price for several cures. Anticipating what your competition will do is a big factor in your success. Patents in particular can really help you or really screw you over in the short-term, although they're fairly easy to work around, but you can do the same thing to the AI. Mucking with the AI's profit margins can really slow them down, giving you a chance to reach (and patent) the very high-level cures before they get a chance to ruin your market.Sometimes you can make just plain bad choices, but usually there's okay options and really great options. There's almost always something you can optimize more if you put thought into it, and if you're shooting for a certain level of revenue or profit you'll be shifting around production lines a lot. I used to hit patches where I'd just need to wait, but now patch 1.01 added a much-needed 5x speed option!Personally, I love this game. The progression has a level of predictability that may put some people off, but the random elements that people keep complaining about actually keep things fresh.

number of helpful: 22 of 29 people (76%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 31, 2015
												I was worried that Big Pharma could turn out to be either too "casual" (like many cheap "tycoon" clickers), or too messy (like games that pretend to be serious, but just throw a bunch of random events at you at increasing pace - Theme Hospital, I'm looking at you). Luckily, that's not the case.   There's far enough depth to raise the game well over the "casual" category. At the same time, its elements are completely transparent, so it doesn't overwhelm you with complexity. It could rather overwhelm you with opportunities. If you enjoy putting your brain to some work, this is a game a doctor would prescribe. Shortly, it perfectly touches the same strings that was touched by good old tycoons you are fond of, adds a surprisingly relevant puzzle element, and flavors the mix with good city sim's spirit of careful planning & continuous improvement. For details, look below.PART 1. MAKING DRUGS   Your goal is to create medicines and make money of them. A complex, profitable medicine usually consists of several components. Making such medicine usually takes many steps: starting an initial mix from a single ingredient and processing the mix through the chain of machinery, changing its concentration and adding other components (in specific order and specific concentrations). Each ingredient has some positive and negative effects. Effects are not just simple "+" or "-": during different processing, each effect could become stronger or weaker, or changed to another, or be removed at all. A mix of several ingredients, as you can guess, is even more complex and could end as many various intricate compounds.    So, making your products is not a straightforward task: there are many methods to make different pills for the very same illness, with various effectivity and side effects. Every production step costs money, so your new creations are usually a compromise between love for humanity and love for money. Plus, when you carefully planned all processing steps and finished your future production line design, you need to fit it into your precious factory space (which is sometimes a puzzle itself).    Plus, you start with a limited set of ingredients and the most primitive machines, so your first drugs are cheap and will not provide for too long. To advance into new delicious markets, you need to jump quickly into expensive research, which cripples your feeble cash flow. And when each of yourr products finally comes to market, there's another story to tell....PART 2. MAKING MONEY    You can estimate the market size and common price level of drugs for specific ilnesses. So, you can estimate your profits and risks of entering chosen markets, and pick out the best opportunity. You carefully look for needed ingredients and improve your technologies to make the product with minimal cost. Better quality can get you a hefty price bonus. But your product is not evaluated instantly. Only real applications show how good your creation turned out to be. So, only after time, statistics shows how effective the drug is, and how many side effects it caused. The price can fall dramatically if the medicine performs poorly, or causes far too many unpleasant experiences. Wrong formula? Your problem. Does demand for raw materials drive their prices up? Your problem. And don't forget you're not alone here. If your competitors saturate the same market with their products, and prices go down, guess what? You got it. Your problem.   What's better: to reach after the tastiest pie with a risk that, in a year, every company will also be biting it? Or to look for stable but safe haven in a sector no one is looking at? To rush into selling an untested formula on industrial scale to make some quick money? Or to test all effects in detail and get the best product and ideal production line that will feed you for years? To flood the competitor's market with cheap alternatives to cut its profits (cause I can, baby)?  Or to use the same precious factory space for a new experimental drug? Your choice, and... yeah, your problem.    "5 hours of gameplay" reviewers usually stop at, or even before, this point. People with more patience realize, unexpectedly, that Easy scenarios pack is a well-hidden tutorial extension, and that single "competitor" actually was a yawning guide in disguise.PART 3. MAKING ENEMIES   When you move to second scenarios pack, dusty gnomes inside your PC are finally convinced that you got used to the rules, and things start to get serious.     The whole new dimension of opportunities: research tree is exploded twice. Equipment which no one has shown you before. New level of formulas you can't even imagine creating without a pen and a paper. Vast number of ways to go. Tremendous amount of things to look into.    The whole new level of warfare: margins are thinner. Side effects' combinations are more sophisticated and widespread. Rivals that, you know, look smart, have different characters and can painfully stab you (and each other) in the back. Wow, now I can patent drugs! What, now THEY can patent drugs?!    All news are a news from a battlefront. Every day is an exhausting race for future riches and fierce dogfight for scarce resources of today. So, do you enjoy to put your brain to some work? Say again? Sorry, wasn't listening. It's all about stress. Got problems with my Prozac production. The composition is a joke. So, what were you saying?

number of helpful: 14 of 15 people (93%) found this review helpful2 people found this review funny
content:
Posted: May 3, 2016
												Big Pharma is a management/strategy/puzzle game where you have to build and manage a medicine company. You can say it’s a business simulation puzzle tycoon. You build, research, develop new medicine all the while trying to maximize profits. There is one part of the game that focuses on the production aspect of the medicines, in this part you have to concentrate on researching new medicine/cures and try to improve your medicine overall. The second part of the game is the economics of your company. You basically have to earn profit and try to improve medicine. Graphics: The graphics are simple yet beautiful looking. The colors are very bright and eye-catching. It almost sort of has that cartoon look. There’s not many options in the graphics menu other than resolution adjustment.  Sound: The music in the game is okay, you won’t get bored from it but it’s nothing to write home about as well. The announcer voice can sometimes become annoying though. Other than that most of the sounds work as they should and not bad at all. Gameplay:  The majority of the game is based on missions, where you start out with $50000 and you have a task. For example the first mission has you earn a certain amount of revenue in 10 years. Most of the missions are like that and as you keep doing missions the next batch of missions gets harder and harder. There’s a lot of missions and even free mode where you can just play without having to worry about anything. There will be a rival company which also influences your company when they introduce new drugs etc. There’s also a puzzle element of fitting your medicine making machinery in a limited space, so figuring that out can be a lot of fun. You can choose from 8 different characters when you start a game. There are perks when you start a new game. E.G a perk where refunding equipment gives you 100% money back instead of regular 50%. You can choose 2 perks, at the beginning there’s only 4 perks unlocked but you can unlock more as you do missions and do the objectives the said perk requires. It’s a very strategic game where everything you do has an effect eventually so you must make your decisions well thought out. Game can be pretty complicated so if you like serious management games, this game is for you.The DLC “Marketing and Malpractice” adds a whole bunch of add-ons to the game such as marketing tools where you can adjust your prices of your drugs as per the demand/demand, you basic economics. This basically changes they way the game works with your competitors as you can undercut their prices. You can give “gifts” and other such to doctors to increase sales. The DLC in my opinion makes the game much more interesting and gives it that new perspective of playing.  Graphics: 8/10  Sound: 7/10  Gameplay: 8/10  Overall: 8/10  Conclusion: Big Pharma is an excellent time waster and a very good business/tycoon/simulator/puzzle game. Though prepare to spend plenty of time learning the ins and outs of the game as it can get very complicated. All in all it’s a fun title and the DLC is pretty nice as well.

number of helpful: 50 of 80 people (63%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 27, 2015
												I played dozens of hours of this game while it was in development and it's been one of my favorite games of the year! I'm happy to see it's now on Steam!Big Pharma is a very unique game. It's best described as a tycoon/management game, mixed with a logistics puzzler or "product chain" puzzler, such as SpaceChem, Infinifactory, or Factorio. Your goal is to create and sell cures ranging from cough suppressants to cancer medicine. The creation process is done through a network of machines and conveyor belts that tinker and transform the potency of raw ingredients into the desired cures (often combating undesired side effects).Often just figuring out how to make a good product is an excellent puzzle in itself, but it's made even more challenging by the ability to perfect the potency of a drug, mix multiple beneficial effects, and remove unwanted side effects. On top of that is a whole financial layer, including an ever-changing market of supply (how much raw ingredients cost) and demand (how badly a cure is needed), further complicated by the competition of rival companies who can drive up ingredient costs, compete for similar cures, and even try to patent certain drugs to prevent others from selling them temporarily. All this is mixed with a large research tree and an interesting procedurally generated list of unlockable ingredients that need to be researched and experimented with in order to advance your company.Sound complex? It is! This game is not a casual experience. As a management game, it strives to be more similar to older "Tycoon" games of the 90's and early 2000's, where succeeding financially is a genuine challenge and there's very little hand-holding when it comes to how to get there. At the same time, the game is definitely in the same vein of puzzle games like the aforementioned SpaceChem; a production puzzle game with no single "right" answers, but millions of wrong ones. Arranging the differently shaped machines and placing conveyor belts is as tricky as trying to figure out the correct combination to make the desired product. But, like the best  of both of those genres, as hard as they are, Big Pharma is actually very easy to learn once you wrap your head around its new ideas, and the payoff is countless ultra-satisfying "I'm a freakin' genius!" moments. The most important thing to note? The tutorial is NOT optional for a new player, and since it's a bit of a wall of text, I imagine that might put some people off.In terms of aesthetic, I absolutely adore the game. The music is absolutely perfect for the subject matter, the UI is one of the cleanest and most functional I've ever seen, and like most good factory-themed games, seeing your products  move down conveyor belts and through wacky machines en mass is an absolute delight.My only worry with the game at the time of writing is that it might have released just slightly too early. For the most part it's fully functional, but there are still a few bugs here and there, and it felt like the balance of things like competitor productivity and patents were still trying to be worked out when the game was released. So far, I've found nothing remotely game-breaking and it's definitely more functional than many things released on Steam, but I'm sure it still could use a few patches (there's also whispers of modding support that might expand the game in the future).Overall, Big Pharma is definitely my kind of game. I'd say it's a must-buy for anyone who likes production puzzlers like SpaceChem or Infinifactory, and a good buy for those who have fond memories of old Tycoon games (with a thematic boost to anyone who loved the game Theme Hospital). Those who want a more casual experience may want to look for something simpler, but for anyone for a great brain-straining puzzle and interesting management game, Big Pharma has your cure!tl;dr+ Great open-ended logistic puzzle gameplay+ Lots of depth, with a good tech tree, many machines, and tons of cures and side effects+ Procedurally generated factory layouts and randomized ingredients make each game feel unique+ Great music and lighthearted aesthetic+ Very challenging with many different ways to succeed+ Interesting business simulation with fluctuating markets and competing companies, adds a new layer to the financial aspect of the game.- Complexity may be off-putting; tutorial NOT optional- Minor bugs, might still need a few balancing tweaks

content:
Posted: December 6, 2015
												Played about 60 hours worth of the game so far, and have enjoyed it.  I have compeleted most of the missions offered in the game and have dabbled in the free-play/custom game mode.Big Pharma is essentially a one part puzzle - one part economic/business simulator, as most of my fellow recommenders have already mentioned.  As it is a two part game, both aspects of it become important at different times. Early game, the business aspect I feel is the more forefront of the two. Money is tight, and the AI at times can be brutal competitors either flooding the market for a product or squeezing you out of one. Not to say the game is too difficult, but for those who love business simulations, the early game is your niche.  Late game however, the game gives way to its puzzle aspect as the more pressing of the two. You both lose opportunities to flex your capital might as well as simply run out of space to place your production lines, usually resulting in having to forgo certain markets alltogether just to produce a high tier product. And one that is impossible to optimize at that. Some of the late game markets are quirky too  I feel - The Male Contraception treatments are apparently permanent (in any form, but pill form specifically just boggles my mind). For those who love business simulations though, I'd recommend giving the game a go.  Its drawbacks to me are more quirky than actual problems with the game itself and you can get decent value from the game at its listed price. In addition, I tink Mark Allsworth did a decent job with the games soundtrack.

												Firstly, this is a bit of a mixed review. I was torn whether or not to give a thums up or thumbs down. Ultimately I went with my gut feeling...Overall this game does what it sets out to do. It is polished, has no bugs that I've run into, and has a good solid ui. So why the thumb down?Basically, as a puzzle game this is a fine game. It combines elements of marketing and math together with problem solving. Did I personally find it fun? Not really, though I'm sure this ticks the box for a lot of you out there. I was expecting a game of resource management (space, cash and materials) whilst competing against the AI in a race to find cures and market them efficiently and grow a company. I suppose I went into the purchase wanting a little more Tycoon/simulation based playstyle, what I bought instead is essentially a "Spacechem" type genre of a game. It just isn't for me. Regarding price. Even if I don't particularly connect with the game type I respect the dev for making such a polished product. They deserve the money spent for the hours it will have taken to produce and publish their work. No complaints there from me, power to them!

content:
Posted: August 8, 2016
												Big Pharma is a combination of tycoon sim, Tetris, and puzzle game.The tycoon sim part is basic; you try to make sure your profits are higher than your expenses, you take out a loan if you're low on cash, you supply more of the drugs that are high in demand, and so on. The simple business management aspect suits the game well.The Tetris part comes from the unique shape of the machines you place in your factory lines and the limited space in which you have to use. In the early game your available space is small, in the late game your factory lines are complex and long, and in both cases maximizing the use of space for optimal output is important. The puzzle part is the meatiest: drug ingredients have components (with negative or positive effects) which can be removed, upgraded, or swapped around using one of your machines. These all have active ranges that vary, and it takes a bit of mental arithmetic to find the sweet spots to create the drug of your choice.When creating drugs, all three parts of the game come into play, making Big Pharma a game with depth and replayability. The campaign missions start you off in an empty factory, which makes gameplay fairly repetitive (though getting randomly generated ingredients and starting ingredients mitigates this somewhat). If you don't mind starting from the beginning for every campaign mission and you're a fan of business sims and casual puzzle games, this could be a good fit.

content:
Posted: September 7, 2015
												Big Pharma...I need to say two things about the game at the start:1. The game is REALLY good, if you like repetitive puzzles with some niche changes over the cause of alot of different challenges pre-set by the game. It also has some sort of custom games mode - I have not touched on it so there might even be infinite amount of games you can play.2. The game itself doesn't try to make you interested in playing more of it. It is a game that you pick up and play and then put down again - it doesn't have a character to it that makes every drug/medicine you make unique in its own flavour. You basically just try to figure out how many positive things you can put on a single thing and sell it.Do I recommend the game? No. The game has an artificial longevity that is repeated in the same pattern over and over and over again. There simply is nothing 'unique' about each challenge you do since you will still build the same machines in every playthru' even if in different ways and shapes - they are still the same.Same thing with the drugs... you need to compete against a competitor's painkillers? Then here's your one ingredience with a side effect - now make it good. Rince and repeat.The game has replayability in the fact that all of the side effects and beneficial effects are random to some degree but like I said before, you are still building the same machines over and over again. Nothing happens except your own ♥♥♥♥-ups which some people find intriguing and I do too... in competitive games, not in games that makes me want to think and figure out what to do next.And this game doesn't really do anything to try and challenge you - there are some mechanics like patents which can make you lock out your competitor's drugs for some time and they can do the same to you but, mechanics like those are just infurating when dealing with an AI where as these mechanics have a place in games when you are able to screw over one of your friends; you are able to get a reaction from them.Overall the game is brilliantly made but doesn't do a whole lot with it. I bought it for 18,39€ where as I think the game's value would be around 9,99€ to 12,99€ - consider it when its on a sale but AVOID IT AT FULL OR NEAR FULL PRICE!

content:
Posted: March 5
												Choosing to recommend this game or not was kind of a dilemma to me. I ended up giving it a positive recommendation, but I'd like to show the pro's and cons so you can weigh it for yourself if you're considering to buy the game.Pro'sMixing up medicine, having to consider side effect and processing costs is actually a lot of funHas a "Theme Hospital" vibe which is fun!Lots of challenging levels that you can complete at Beginner, Advanced or Master level. Difficulty felt just right!ConsNo multiplayerThere are these "competitors" who you can't see or hear much about, only that they are working on the same market as you and, of course, against you. I'd love to have seen their companies too!Progression felt rather shallow; there aren't many machines to use. You can combine a lot however which is great, but perfecting medicine often results in high processing costs, making your drug unprofitable which is stopping you from making awesomely thought out layouts.At it's current price-point, there's not enough the game has to offer. I really enjoyed this game, but at some point I had the feeling of "Ok, well this is it" and hit a wall when I couldn't really progress any further. The game's various levels really do put up a good effort to delay that feeling though and it definitely improves replayability, but to me that didn't feel like a strong enough reason to keep playing. I feel that a game like Factorio would be a better choice for a comparable game. Big Pharma is definitely fun while it lasts, so consider getting it in sale; I'd value it at about 10 bucks.

												First off: I own this game from their website before the steam release, so my playtime is higher than the 0.4 hours it claims right now.TLDR: Even though I like many aspects of the game, I can not recommend it at its price as it will not keep you entertained for very long.Do I somewhat like the game? Yes.Would I recommend it? Not really, especially not for 23 Euros.I love the setting, I feel there should be way more disease/medical-related games and I do enjoy the graphics, by which I mean I don't mind the simplicity. I like the making of new drugs, the setting up of belts/arrangements, the tight budget, the slight humour, the ideas like exploration and the reasearch tree.So why wouldn't I recommend it? Because it gets boring, and it does so rather quick. The reason for this is, that its repetetive. Gamesessions usually are done in 1-3 Hours depending on difficulty and consist of you researching new techs and producing new medications with increased difficulty in the setup of your conveyer-belts.The Problem is that its the same each mission. And the Drugs/Ingredients are completly interchangeable. Unless youre a "Letsplayer" you wont care for the name of the made-up Drugs/Ingredients within seconds but they will just be stats like "increase/decrease concentration by 3" so thats all you do.You find the easiest way to reach that wanted concentration. And theres only (when fully researched) like 3 ways of increasing decreasing, meaning +/- 1 ; +/-3 ; half/double. So thats not hard! In fact nothing is really "hard" in this game. Theres no need to make difficult choices, as you will most likely produce every medice you can as far as research and exploration go, since every "tick" gives money, theres also no need to think about if you should keep the medicine going - if it ticks in money, keep it, if it loses money, replace it.The result is a very easy game and the "challange" comes from increasingly hard scenarios. But this doesn't mean anything interesting like "do this-and-that with 3 rooms" or so, no, while there are ~5 different types on missions they all play the same, as you just need to make more of the best kind of medicine, cure a number of people, make some money or something along those lines, so they all mean you build up your, lets say "empire" and then at some point you win. And weather your task is to make 5-super-medicines or to make X Million $ doesnt matter as you do the very same thing. The Difficulty of the Game (which does go quite high in the late game) only comes from increasingly narrow timelimits, so the medium and hard difficulty is identical, except in one you need to make (lets say, not sure about the real number right now as it doesnt matter) 5 Milion in 10 years and on hard its 10 Million in 5 Years.So after 10 hours lets say you will start more than your 10th game (the easy games go by rather fast) and you will do the very same thing the 10th time in a row, still not caring. And since setting up the conveyer belt-systems is the only real aspect, and you do that about once every 5 minutes, you will have done that about 120 times. And then its just routine, theres no fun to be had (there hasn't been in quite a while) and all you do is click your new belt, wait for money to pour in, click your new belt a.s.o.

content:
Posted: September 25, 2016
												Overall, I had fun with the game. Nothing exposes your inner evil than becoming a pharmaceutical executive. The gameplay is not too complex, mostly based around creating production lines increasing and decreasing concentration or adding new ingredients to reach the higher tier drugs or to add special effects. Building machinery is similar to tetris: rotate the fixed input and output points until the shortest connection between them is possible or they take up the least amount of place.Few issues:- Most maps are badly designed, as a result of the tetris-like elements. Buildings are oddly shaped, full of narrow passages and corridors that make placing fixed sized and shaped machines frustrating or requiring a lot of moving around. I would personally prefer a more Prison Architect style gameplay where I can freely design buildings to suit my needs.- Just as real medical research, I assume, production lines involve certain amount of rial and error. Some machines remove some effects, but so far I found no explanation for that. The mixers lack labeling on input, so the first mix is a trial and error in determining what will be the base and what the additive.- The upgrade system is uninspiring. Purely decrease the operating cost of a machine by x amount of money. No tech to increase speed, improve supply, or anything more meaningful. A deeper, more diverse research system would be nice.- The AI does weird things. I developed Drug A. Cornered the market to 90%. The AI developed Drug B, a less effective version of Drug A. Got the 10%. So far so good. But over time, based on its less effective drug, with a higher price tag and a lower sales rating, it managed to muscle me out of the whole market with no rational explanation.- The patent system is ridiculous and broken, just like in real life I guess. I have been selling a drug I developed ahead of the competitors for 10 years. Then the AI slaps a patent on it, and retroactively pulls mine off the market. That would be like me patenting apples and hitting all fruit farmers with a cease and desist letter which there is no recourse for. It is an unfair, broken and gimmicky system that should not be in the game in its current form. Drugs already on the market should not be subject to the system, it should be an option once you developed a new drug.In conclusion, I do not regret my purchase. The game is fun albeit simplistic and sometimes a bit rough around the edges. It is still an entertaining management game. With some additional elements a sequel to it could be a really good game.

content:
Posted: July 9, 2016
												In Big Pharma, you take the role of a CEO of a pharmaceutical company, and you have to take your fledgling company from minor painkiller pusher to mega-corporate cancer killer.At the start of the game, you are dumped into an empty factory lot where you will be able to start building production machines and start manufacturing some cures. Each segment of the factory will have an input point where you can choose to pull through certain ingredients which may or may not have positive attributes. Running these ingredients through a careful setup of specific machines will either emphasise or dissipate the base positive or negative effects of your ingredients. Once you’re happy with the result, throw what you have into a pill machine and pipe it out through one of your output points where it will be given a name and shipped off into the world to be sold. You can also put scientists hard at work to research some brand new machines and ingredients, or simply improve existing ones. This is a nice way to improve the quality of your production lines and keep a consistent, stable way of producing reliable cures and boost profits the legitimate way.The Marketing and Malpractice DLC helps to give you more control on the money side of things, and instead of just selling a cure for a set price throughout you can hike the cost of a drug when you know the demand is high and people are in desperate need of it; something as simple as a paracetamol may be in high demand after a tragedy somewhere in the world, and you can use it as an opportunity to charge a fortune for it. You can also undercut a competitor to gain your own company more money at the expense of theirs, adding new ways to play Big Pharma and causing you to be savvy off the production floor as well.Big Pharma does feel unique, as it’s rare to get an economic/sim game that was built from the design level up to be a morality play on human greed.People who enjoy business sims, and want to engage with something that requires planning without overzealous micromangement may find Big Pharma to be the cure.THE GOOD- Unique morality play in a sim game- Addictive gameplay - Adds a new personal approach to playing- Perks systemTHE BAD- Feels somewhat barren- Suffers from repetitive gameplay- Once you’ve played around with the features it loses appealDISASTER | BAD | MEDIOCRE | OKAY | GOOD | GREAT | AMAZING | MASTERPIECE

number of helpful: 8 of 10 people (80%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 6, 2015
												The game focuses on setting up the production lines - it really isn't a business sim, but I don't think the game suffers because of it. Combining ingredients to get the desired effects, working within the confinements of your factory - there is plenty to think about. It can be very satisfying to tweak a production line to operate more efficiently, or to engineer out one of the pesky side effects. Probably do to my inability to think ahead, I'd have to re engineer my plans to overcome an obstacle I didn't anticipate. Researching better equipment opens up more options to formulate your products.On the first advanced scenario, money was much tighter and the game provided a tense challenge. Sometimes competing against the AI feels arbitrary, maybe because they're mostly just messages that pop up. I don't feel like they're going through the same process as me. They are effective though - I would curse them when they patented a cure that was on my production line and they provide for some interesting moments.My two main wishes are more fast forward levels and an online leaderboards so I can chase my friends' scores. Another nice touch would be to have a 'random' setting for each parameter when setting up a custom game. Many times games are more enjoyable if the player doesn't know quite what to expect and have to adjust their play once they discover what's going on.I've read some people's complaints about the amount of content included in Big Parma and I don't get where they're coming from. There are many scenarios, taking hours to complete. Setting up a custom game offers more play for those who want it too.So, if you enjoy setting up and tinkering with production lines, my guess is that you'll like Big Pharma. My full review can be found here.[www.oneguytoomanygames.com]

number of helpful: 20 of 33 people (61%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 14, 2016
												Big Pharma requires you to fit a number of tetris-shaped machines in as little space as possible in order to make drugs for profit. I'd love to say there was more to the game than that, but sadly there really isn't. All the challenges are basically the same, which makes the game very repetitive and it gets boring very, very fast. SImply not worth the price. You can get mobile games for free that are much more worthwhile and will give you many more hours of entertainment.I bought this in early access (and got the Steam version for free, but never played it on Steam) and expected a lot more to be added to the game, but was then surprised when the release date was announced, constantly thinking "that has to be a mistake, it's not remotely done." But no, Tim considered it done and it was released. Sorry, Tim, but you made a bad game.The good part:- Figuring out how to turn ingredients into drugs using as few machines as possible is fun, at first. - Trying to create crazy drugs by combining different cures that aren't normally combined can be fun, at first.- Watching all the machines work is fun, for a while.- You can name all your drugs whatever you want, which is also compeltely pointless because there's no multiplayer so there's no one to laugh at the names you use.But then comes all the bad (and the list is only short because there's so little to the game):You have AI opponents who for the most part only seem to be there as decoration. They're no real challenge and even with the patents it's not a problem to beat them because you can just make another drug that's slightly different. You never feel cornered or like you have to rush. The only challenge remains beating the timer if you care at all about scoring gold on everything (which in itself doesn't earn you anything whatsoever other than a golden line on the scenario selection screen).Once you beat the first scenario you know how to beat the rest of the game. The only thing that changes is how fast you have to make your money and what drugs you can make. Nothing else changes.Tim (the developer) has a background in simple mobile games and it shows in Big Pharma: It lacks depth, it lacks complexity, and everything is over-simplified to the point where you have no control over any of the things that would have made the game remotely interesting. I wasn't the only one who asked for a more complex economy, but Tim felt it wasn't needed. Unfortuntely having no control over the economy means it doesn't really matter what you do because prices fluctuate at random. It also means that half the info screens don't matter because you can't do much at all to affect your economy anyway.Tim's idea that "scoring gold on a mission can be incredibly motivating" doesn't fly when the game is so incredibly boring to play and has no real content. You simply have nothing to do, ever, other than plopping down the machines, connecting them with belts, and trying not to lose count of whether you needed two or three machines to get the right concentration.Meanwhile you scream for more to do and bang your head against the wall to express your frustration for yet another incomplete game that was released with no plans for more content.

content:
Posted: August 28, 2015
												Big Pharma is a tycoon-style game based around pharmaceutical development. It holds the isometric view of classic games like Rollercoaster Tycoon while being graphically sleek. As with its tycoon-style roots, it also contains puzzle elements as the equipment you must use act as puzzle pieces that you must fit together in a fixed amount of space.So what makes this game appealing?Firstly, it's a management simulation game. If you're as big a fan as Rollercoaster Tycoon as I am, chances are you'll enjoy this game just on the style of the game alone.As for how the levels are set up, there are several categories of scenarios each with their own set missions. These categories range from Beginner to Advanced difficulties, along with Quick Play and Crippling Debt categories, the last of which severely handicaps you if you're looking for a challenge!When it comes to dropping into a scenario, the building space and ingredients you have at your disposal are completely randomized. This means you can start the game with a nice area to start building in, or perhaps a not so nice area. It also means that you can have ingredients that induce negative side effects or not. But no fear! You can buy more space with the money you have and discover more ingredients through exploring different biomes for new raw materials to make cures to illnesses with so overcoming a rough start is entirely doable.Exploring for new ingredients is a must as well as researching new methods to manipulate the drugs to turn them into cures. The ingredient system works very well in my opinion. Sometimes you just have to change the concentration of the ingredient to make higher level cures but sometimes you also need to mix it just right with catalysts to make the drug a higher selling product which adds more layers of depth to production.With all that, there are also competitors that influence the drug market in their own unique way that isn't the same each time you play. Competitors may release the same drug as you have, saturating the market with supply which brings the price of the drug down a little. So release patents to stop them and hope they don't do the same to you!This game, while simple at its core, offers a great managing experience and varying levels of challenge even within each mission through three different win-states. The win-states are like a "Bronze, Silver, Gold" medal type system which rewards both casual and hectic play.What may users not like about the game?If you’re like me that wants to try to perfect everything and max out the space you’re given? There's ALWAYS something that requires your attention, requiring you to be ready to do a whole list of things until you end up closing out of the game or pause it to take the dog for a walk. There's no real time to take a step back and admire what you create or take a breather. Even on the beginner levels there are always ways to enhance production, make new production lines, enhance ingredient discovery or research, etc. However, you can choose to take the game slow if you want; there’s nothing stopping you but the goals you set for yourself when you drop in!Also just a note, this is one of those games that you need to play the tutorial to really get a good foundation on how to play.If you're still indecisive, I've made a small video series of me playing the game trying to reach master level on the game. I jump right into it and explain how everything works and I believe you'll know if it's a game for you within a few minutes of skimming through gameplay.


YouTube™ Video: Big Pharma - Ep. 1 - Mastering Beginner: "Easing Some Pain" - Let's Play 

			Views: 1,358		

			Big Pharma is a tycoon-style game based around pharmaceutical development. It holds the isometric view of classic games like Rollercoaster Tycoon while being graphically modern.		

Aside from that, have fun making drugs that give people headaches while simultaneously cure migraines!

If you hate puzzles, then find something else. Big Pharma is definitely a problem solving, puzzle game. That's the core feature!

number of helpful: 7 of 10 people (70%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 4, 2015
												Big Pharma is obviously a business management sim, but it has some unique things going for it that distinguish it from other types of business management sims and give it a unique hook.First let's discuss the normal business management aspects. You run a company that makes drugs, and there are essentially three areas of the company you have to manage. The first is that you need the space and the equipment to make the drugs, which means you will need to spend capital to purchase floor space and then you will need to spend more capital to purchase machines to go on that floor space that are used to make your drugs. (There is a LOT more complexity to this part of the game, but we'll get into that later.) The second area is research, which is pretty much just an unlock tree. You pay an initial flat rate to hire a scientist and then also pay each scientist by the hour. The more scientists you have on payroll, the more quickly you'll rack up research points, but that obviously gets expensive, so you need to balance with your income. Research unlocks new machines, new shipping methods, access to new drug recipes, ability to file patents on your recipes, and more. The third area is exploration, which is a tree similar to the research tree. In this area you pay a flat rate to hire explorers and then also pay them by the hour. You deploy your explorers to search jungles, deserts, oceans, etc for new or rare ingredients. By discovering new ingredients with new properties, you have access to new recipes that can be used to make a variety of new drugs. Explorers also have their own research points which you can spend to reduce the purchase price of ingredients and reduce your cost of materials.These are the basics. Know that you will always have rival companies that are manufacturing and selling drugs in competition with you, and if the rival company's drugs are of a better quality than yours, they can eat up your market share (i.e. you will make fewer sales and earn less money due to your competitor stealing your customers). In the early modes and difficulties, competitors are a breeze to deal with. They can be more of a menace in later modes, though, for sure.Okay, so what is the unique hook? The unique hook lies in purchasing floor space and machines and then assembling production lines. It is a complicated PUZZLE. Bear with me, because this gets a tad complex. Every ingredient you have to work with has four effect slots, and those four slots are filled with effects. The slots can either contain a curative effect, a negative effect, or simply be empty. The easiest ingredients to work with tend to have one curative effect and one negative effect. The more difficult ingredients have one curative effect and three negative effects. In addition to these effect slots, each ingredient also has a CONCENTRATION value that can be anywhere between 1 and 20. The higher the number, the higher the concentration. Each of the effects in the four slots has a random concentration interval assigned to it, and the effect is only ACTIVE if the concentration falls within that interval. For example, if the ingredient has the curative effect SOOTHES COLD that is active between 11-14, and the negative effect CAUSES CONSTIPATION that is active between 5-12, and the default concentration of the ingredient is 12, then THAT means that both effects are active in the ingredient, so you have to put the ingredient through a machine that will change the concentration so that the curative effect is active and the negative effect is not active. So if you change the concentration to 13, it is still within range to soothe colds, but it will no longer cause constipation. Get it? Still with me? It gets even crazier.Okay, so obviously there are machines that can change the concentration value of an ingredient to alter the effects. But sometimes you have ingredients with three negative effects and it is literally impossible to deactivate all of the negative side effects, so then what do you do? Well, there are also machines that can shake up the order of the effect slots, and machines that can swap effects between two ingredients. So if you're clever, you can swap negative effects out and positive effects in. In some situations, you can even create super drugs that have multiple positive effects! The problem is that it can require a lot more machines to make these crazy drugs, which is not only more expensive to purchase the machines, but each machine also has a per-use cost as well, so it is in your best interest to have as few machines as possible. UGH. DECISIONS.There are other ways to deal with negative side effects as well. For example, you eventually learn that not only does every effect have an active range, but every effect also has a "sweet spot" number, which is a specific number between 1 and 20 where the effect is 100% effective. So you can research your own drugs to find the sweet spots and improve your drug quality, which is important so that your competitor doesn't steal your buys with better quality drugs. And of course there are some interesting technologies you can unlock that don't really pertain to concentrations or effects but are still highly useful in other ways. There is really A LOT in here to learn and figure out.Oh, and don't forget that you actually have to manually place each machine on the factory floor, rotate it, hook up the conveyor belts yourself, etc. Sometimes you have enough funds to set up a production line for a new drug, but you're out of floor space because you built too many huge production lines and you can't fit the new one in there. (Discontinue a line of drugs to make room for a new one? DECISIONS.) So there is also a spatial puzzle element of using the fewest machines possible, laying the conveyors to actually complete the circuit, arranging your machines and production lines in such a way that it doesn't get in the way of future building and/or allows you to upgrade or expand the current production line later as new ingredients become available.There are lots of different difficulties, modes, and objectives to play. There is even a sandbox mode where you can get all machines, all tech, and are given infinite money, so you can experiment with the machines to figure out what all of them do. (Some people may be confused about how the mixer works at first, so having a safe place to test and observe it is helpful. Combining the mixer and shaker is an advanced gameplay strategy that is difficult to understand or use without a bit of practice and experimentation, so sandbox mode helps with that as well.)Mods are available from the dev if you want to change up certain aspects of the game. For example, some people (including me) don't think it makes much sense that by default it is impossible to move conveyor belts without selling them and rebuying them at a loss, so you lose money for just correcting/moving conveyors (which is not the case with machines). So there is a mod to make conveyor belts free, which I recommend. (Though what they should have done for best balance, IMO, is just make the buy/sell price the same.)Tutorial is well done. It is very hands on, but also easy to skim through quickly for those who have little patience and just want to get down to business (i.e. me).Highly recommended for business sim lovers---especially if you like the idea of having some headscratching and puzzling thrown into the mix. You REALLY have to plan with this one.

content:
Posted: August 28, 2015
												I've been playing this game since its early beta days back in June 2015. Big Pharma might look like your run of the mill tycoon game, but it is much deeper than that. The concentration system for drugs, the random ingrediant generation and robust AI compeditor performance (especially on higher difficulty levels) lends this to be a very interesting and *very* replayable game. Sure the random nature might mean that the available ingrediants are awesome in one game and suck in the next...but since everybody in the game plays with the same pool of ingrediants, the challenge is to make the most of what is available. This is also a part puzzle game as you try to figure out how to cram your more and more complex production lines into a limited space. It can be extremely satisfying to have nearly every square inch of an area filled to the brim with drug machinery humming with their various drug modifying operations. The tech tree is laid out in a logical but still strategic manner. Researching techs takes scientists and keeping scientists employed is expensive, so deciding which techs to go for in which order is important. Given the variable ingrediants each game, you aren't going to always want the same path down the tech tree each game. Not to mention you have to weight the options of leaving your scientists idle, which generates research points that are used to upgrade your equipment (making it cheaper to operate) or use them to research new techs, giving you access to brand new equipment or other discounts. If you are a fan of business tycoon games at all, this game is for you. It is absolutely worth the price of admission.

content:
Posted: September 27, 2016
												This game is one of my best recent purchases. I got this at 66% off, but 21 hours in, I can definitely say it is worth full price.I completed the tutorials in about 90 minutes, and it has taken me a further 20 hours to beat all the beginner levels to Master standard.I've just moved up to Intermediate level, and discovered that there are a whole load of new machines and research topics, plus more cures, ingredients, side-effects, and ways to combine them together! I wasn't expecting such a leap in complexity, and I still have not checked out the Advanced levels yet! I've also noticed, that many of the achievements seem interesting, and might be worth pursuing in their own right.Before purchasing. I read some of the negative reviews, which mentioned the randomness of the game, and repetitive nature of the gameplay. Sure, some of it is repetitive; when starting a new level, you have to build up your factory and income, but the randomness is a good thing - in different games, different ingredients lead to different cures and side-effects, and you have to combine them in different combinations. You have to think - you can't just keep repeating the same cures you developed in previous games. In my view, that's a very good thing!There are so many aspects of this game, and it is much deeper than I expected. I've yet to unlock and discover all the elements of the game, but already I can see the potential for creating super drugs which cure multiple illnesses at once, and could potentially be worth thousands of dollars. That kind of drug won't be easy to create, but is definitely doable if you make the right combinations.Do yourself a favour, and just buy it!

												At its heart, this is a puzzle game.  Fairly easy to learn, moderately difficult to master.  It's got a lot more depth than it appears at first.  The descriptions and videos are very forward about what type of game this is.  This is NOT a Theme Hospital type game.  It's a puzzle game where you create manufacturing lines to create medications for the hospitals and pharmacies.  If you watch a video and it looks fun, you'll love the game.  If you watch the videos and it looks boring, you definitely will be bored.Insta-buy on sale.  Highly recommended on retail price.  I've had a lot of fun with this game!

number of helpful: 4 of 5 people (80%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 14, 2015
												I heard about this game and saw a couple of lets plays on it, then bought it.  It is a very simple game, but it is not easy.  You start with a production floor, which can be increased.  The production floor is randomly generated, so it is different on every game.  The ingredients are also randomly generated with both positive and negative affects.  There are 20+ challenges with 3 different levels of completion each.  Not to mention the equipment and upgrades.  Is it repetitious at times, yes, but so are every other game in a similar genre.  The randomized aspects of the game keeps you from doing the same exact thing from challenge to challenge.  And the game does not take itself too seriously.  Yes, you can make a migraine medication that has headaches as a side affect.  And lets not forget the names of the medications you create.  You can name them yourself, or have the computer do it for you.  With a female contraception called (by the computer) Jeff's Preg Be-Gone, how could you name anything better than that.Overall, it is a good game, and I paid full price for it, $25.  I do not normally pay full price on games, but wanted to support the developer.

number of helpful: 23 of 42 people (55%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 11, 2015
												Have you ever played an RTS where you get really immersed in building the perfect base, but every new level throws away your hard work and forces you to start again from scratch? Big Pharma is like a distilled version of that. It has 35 levels, all of which start you near the bottom of the tech tree. Pretty much every level will start the same - 10-20 minutes of building low-level supply chains, trying to get a profit while you wait for research to unlock. To make matters worse, building the supply chains is actually really tedious as you have to jump through the menus to research each stage of the process before you build it. You're constantly fighting to make a profit, and many of the levels have time limits. Don't let my high playtime fool you - I was afk for a lot of that. Big Pharma is only good for about 3 hours. After that, there's just too much tedium and not enough fun.

content:
Posted: September 6, 2015
												My fear in purchasing this was that I'd be bored of it in 5 minutes.  I'm glad to say that I was wrong.Don't be fooled by the simple, clean UI---Big Pharma is a surprisingly deep simulator where the logistical puzzle of placing machinery to assemble your drugs is the least of your worries.  For me, the real difficulty of the game was interacting with the drug market, where you must balance drug prices, market saturation & also keep an eye on what your competitors are doing (if they're importing the same ingredient as you, for example, that ingredient may become oversaturated & its price will rise, hurting your bottom line).You can flood the market with a side effect-laden drug for some quick cash if you want, but consumers will eventually figure it out & punish you as your cure rating drops & your drug starts losing money.My only criticism of the game so far is that it lacks a planning stage where you can lay out your production lines in advance.  I had to repeatedly switch between the Ingredients & Cures tabs to work out how to develop a level 3 cure, and keeping track of the machines that I needed quickly became overwhelming.  In the end, I'd go to the Production tab to place a couple machines, then back to the Ingredients & Cures tabs to figure out what machines to place next.A planning stage that tells you the concentrations/catalysts of imported ingredients (from the Ingredients tab), how to get to the cure (from the Cures tab) & the concentration/catalyst of the drug as it exits each machine in the planned line would be incredibly useful.  Then click a button to commit the entire thing, and you're done.Also, when I'm deciding which machines to upgrade, it'd be very helpful to know how many of that machine I have across all my production lines.  For now, I can scan the lines to get a rough idea, but this is another example of mental gymnastics that the game could eliminate.Big Pharma is a game that I wouldn't hesitate to pick up on sale.  I'll be following this one for sequels/expansions.(This review was for version 1.00.04 of the game.)

number of helpful: 5 of 7 people (71%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 5, 2015
												Interesting game, but a bit long and tedious.  Game could seriously benefit from faster speed acceleration than is currently available.  The lack of an area selection tool to move or delete sections of production line is also a noticeable negative.  The pieces all have set shapes, which is part of the puzzle element of creating drugs.  But this works to the games disadvantage as well.  You end up with such chaotic and ugly lines of production that you lose some of the joy and pride of accomplishing a difficult creation.  I'd rather have the option of choosing between multiple shapes for each device.  It would also be very nice to feed one device directly into another without a conveyor belt.Later on in each mission, you have a large amount of ingredients and production lines.  There is no nice clean link between the screens that show ingredients, production, and your outputs.  It would be extremely helpful to show something as simple as "You are buying 90 of these per month.  This ingredient is used in 3 outputs".  This also doesn't belong on the giant graph/screen on the right once you click on an ingredient.  It should be in the descriptor block for each ingredient.Click on an ingredient, drug on the cures page, or on one of your drugs under the company page, should show you where on the production map those items are being imported or exported.  This would alleviate some of the tedium.  Or at least on the production map you should be able to zoom way out, and still see the ingredient and output icons that you can see while zoomed in.  Finding one light pink pill on a jumbled messy map is annoying.If you want a puzzle game, go play Infinifactory.  For an economic sim game, the lack of reporting and inspection into how things are going are lackluster.  For a casual game, each level just takes too long.

content:
Posted: January 18, 2016
												I wish there was a way to write a neutral, as I could go either way on this game.Obviously, I have played a lot of hours, but as another reviewer mentioned, you get to the point of wanting to complete all the missions/scenarios instead of playing for fun.Figuring out how the machines work, strategies for making money, etc are fun at first.  What happens is it takes some time to get machines unlocked, etc. while playing in missions, so you find yourself doing essentially the same strategy for every scenario up to the point of fulfilling the mission objectives.  For example, several missions are "earn xxx profit in xxx time" - well that's easy enough once you have done it for $1,000,000 you can do it for $10,000,000.  There are missions like "cure xxx xxx times" or "supply xxx drugs", again, once you do those once, it's fairly easy to repeat.  The AI players are pretty much a non-threat.I believe there's a good 20 hours of playtime in the game.  After that, it starts to become repetitive.My advise:  Buy it on sale.  $15 or under would be OK.To the devs:  Game is good but too expensive for what it is - I wish the missions were more varied.  I wish you could really ramp up the difficulty and the AI was an actual competitior.  For example, being able to bankrupt the AI or having the AI complete the same mission objectives you are would be good.

Posted: September 24, 2016
												This game is like the baby brother of factorio. There's still plenty to do though. Completing all the cure's even in the largest of maps at the same time is no easy feat (assuming your also pumping out each of its predesessors). Its pretty fun, looks good. Concept is great and gameplay is smooth and intuitive.HOWEVER.. i honestly dont think its worth £18.99. I grabbed it on sale for £7.20 or something with the DLC and it is totally worth that as after 7.7 hours played so far i would say for me there's not a great deal of replay value. Whereas Factorio being outside, and much MUCH bigger you're able to plan your routes etc far more imaginatively and keep pressing for that every more efficent factory. This, not so much as even with changing building sizes you're still always limited and that in itself is great to start with but when you have to start removing production queues to fit in another stage of anoter drug it lets it down a little for me.So yes, i would recommend this game to anyone who likes these kinda games, its great if not a little limited. Pick it up on sale if you can as i would have been left slightly dissapointed at full price but had fun none the less.

content:
Posted: December 4, 2016
 Pharmaceutical Manufacturing Simulator


YouTube™ Video: Big Pharma || The Basics || Pharmaceutical Manufacturing Simulator || Part 1 

			Views: 121		

			#bigpharma http://store.steampowered.com/app/344850/ ♦Add me on Steam: http://steamcommunity.com/id/desolater_iv/ ♦Twitter: https://twitter.com/DESOLATER_IV		

+ The gameplay is extremely addicting. Basically you are building a lab full of assembly lines that take raw ingredients and converts them into medicine or pills to sell for profit.+  Visually the game looks great with a very nice clean charming style. Once you build a bunch of machines it can be very entertaining to just sit back and watch your factory essentially print money.+ A lot of strategy and planning is involved while designing your machines. You will often have to move around or completely change a line to develop an even greater product. Every machine has a different entry and exit point, so you really have to keep in mind how much space you have, and try to make things compact.+ Surprisingly complex. I found the game to be a tad hard to learn at first, but once you grasp the concept it will feel very rewarding as you learn how to upgrade and mix ingredients to form greater level cures.+ A LOAD of content. If you plan on beating the game I'm sure you can spend over 40 hours easily as each level is quite time consuming. (which is not a bad thing)- The tutorials were very lengthly and a bit tedius to get through as they have you read through a bunch of instructions rather than introducing the mechanics in a more fun way. (A narrator could have helped)- There isn't any information that tells you the supply / demand for each type of drug. Therefor, you do not really have any idea what a new drug will sell for. I'd often find myself spending quite a bit upgrading an assembly line to make a higher tier medication only to find out that the new medication was not selling for much and there's no way I could have known.

content:
Posted: October 4, 2015
												Great game, did not regret buying it. It's not the game you will be playing like forever, but a couple of dozens of hours and an ok replayability is here. The economic part is not that strong, but it is still there hidden under the hood, and understanding some of those not too simple under the hood interactions is crucial for beating the master level of more difficult missions. The great thing about the game is the puzzles of fitting every processing unit into your tight area and the tradeoffs of what exactly you want to produce: a cheap low quality product, an expensive perfect medicine with no side effects, maybe you make cream instead of pills to reduce side effects instead of expensive process of removing it, or screw everything and simply do not produce that type of medicine. And those competitors with their patents...rrr! Great stuff, quite simple at a glance, quite challenging if you want to master it, that's what I want of the game that does not pretend to be the best in genre for all times but still is way above average thanks to a number of small but enjoyable details. I feel the game could even be one of the best of its kind if added a bit more divercity, deepness and maybe an additional few layers of what you work with, hopefully in the same manner the complexity already exists: not critical to know if you don't want to bother but extremely useful to max out your perfomance.

content:
Posted: September 24, 2015
												Big Pharma is a logistics min/max puzzle game mixed with a lightweight market simulation.  You'll make decisions regarding the quality of your cures vs. the strength of their side effects vs. the profit margins you get for selling them vs. the randomly-generated sized and shaped warehouses available to build in.To go along with this, you'll have to work through a Research tree to gain access to better equipment and new ingredients as well as many ways to discount the various costs and/or efficienices in the game.  The better equipment is needed for making higher-end cures as well as making cures with less overall machines that might require more creative conveyor belt routing.  Some machines do take more turns to complete an action so now I need to build another conveyor line going this way and then bring them back together over here and then I just need to...  ahem...  There's also an Ingredients tree where you'll send explorers to various places to unlock the ability to cure other diseases.  Some of these ingredients have special catalysts that you'll need to use to upgrade other ingredients.  Upgrading lets you develop cures for the more difficult and expensive diseases to treat.  All ingredients have side effects though that can vary widely - adding another layer of difficulty.  Inactive explorers will help you reduce the costs of your ingredients as well so you can bring up your profit margins without having to sacrifice a cure's quality because that stupid jerk other company is stealing my marketshare and my patent won't finish for another three months and staying in the green is tough right now so I just need to... ahem...The game's main story mode has a really great variety of challenges to play through.  The tutorial levels are a spot-on introduction to the game and do a good job of preparing the player for the regular game.  The difficulty does ramp up pretty quickly between the columns - especially when there are additional competitors in the game.  Some of the levels are really straight-forward and you'll knock them out in no time flat.  Other levels are like trying to eat frosted mini-wheat cereal without milk, for lunch, while sprinting across the Sahara Desert being chased by whatever crazy hallucinations the sun poisoning has developed because writing this review is going on too long now so I just need to... ahem...Go play some more!Tldr; This is one of those games that makes me physically stop and ensure I don't have anything else going on for the next 2-7 hour long binge session.

number of helpful: 3 of 4 people (75%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 27, 2016
												Surprisingly good game. Put way more hours into this than I thought I ever would and I keep on playing. It keeps you engaged, when you work a problem out like compacting a production line into the smallest space possible in a cramped factory you legit feel good about it. Then your heart sinks when the market for that product falls out. Luckily you can save money, look for another ingredient that needs to be processed in a similar manner and with minimal effort crank out another drug. Or instead of selling the machinery at a loss you could re-use machinery different configurations or manufacturing lines to make a completely new process for another ingredient. Another thing, ingredients are randomized. This means you cannot make the same thing the same way. Ever. Each time you load a new level you have to think on the fly, formulate what conentrations you want, and if it's worth processing an ingredient enough to remove side effects. Sometimes side effects disappear with almost no effort, other times it's too cost prohibitive to even try unelss you want to make a drug at a profit-loss. What furthers the gameplay is competition. There are AI that can do exactly what you do in the game. All the dirty tricks and good recipes. They might not be as good as a human right out of the gate, you are typically the first to release a product, but each personality of AI can specialize in certain things. The CEO fellow goes around putting patents on easily made drugs like a prick, the nerdy looking old man makes very high-level drugs typically quicker than I would, sometimes an AI will make enough of a product that it drops market demand so you won't be on top in that market. This helps keep the game very fresh at all times, you don't know which AI you are facing and they can give you a run for your money at times. I can keep raving on for hours. I like this game a lot. It's not expensive, it's very cheap for what you get. It can run on Linux just fine, I play it on LinuxMint17 and the mouse isn't as responsive as windows but this isn't an FPS, you can pause this game any time you want. The expansion is an honest expansion and worth the $6 full price, adds so much more to Big Pharma. Very good game, it genuinely surprised me how much fun it is.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 8, 2016
												OverviewI have played for over 30 hours without mods or cheats and do not own the expansion pack. So far I have managed to progress to Intermediate level in the scenarios. From my experience this game is what a sim management should be.  With a bit of twisted humour thrown into the mix seen in classics such as Theme Hospital, Big Pharma is beautifully made and very entertaining with a lot of replayability. Interface and graphicsThe main menu looks like a mobile port but don't be fooled! The simplistic buttons and side menus in the main game add to the overall functionality of the game. There are options to change the resolution, sound and graphic quality in the game. The graphics are in the cartoon style. I personally prefer this because cartoon style graphics will age much slower than the more realistically styled games, if at all.GameplayThere are 3 game modes for you to play - Free Play, Custom Game and Scenario. Free Play is the sandbox level where every machine and research branch is already unlocked and you have no money. Custom Game is where you set your own criteria to win the game. All of the goals/criteria in the game are number based and it would be nice to have a little more variety in how you win like being the most or least ethical competitor in game (but this might be in the expansion). Other than that the gameplay is solid. There is a lot of scope for replayability. There are 3 ranks in each game: standard, expert and master. The higher up the rank, either you have to do more within the standard time limit, or you have a shorter amount of time to complete your criteria. It's not just about what the game tells you to do as I find that I set myself personal goals long after I have finished my game criteria on a certain level. A few funny bugsI have experienced some world events that were not logical at certain times. An example of this is the 'mild winter' event that popped up in May. I was also stuck on the 'Keep calm and carry on' scenario for a bit because none of the raw ingredients that were available to be explored in the game had the certain enzyme that I needed to be able to upgrade my drug to an anti-anxiety treatment. I made sure to explore all of the available areas.My verdictThis is a great game. It gets really addictive so don't pick this game up if you want to be productive. A solid 10.

number of helpful: 4 of 7 people (57%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 27, 2015
												Have played a lot of this game before it reached Steam. It has a very tycoon feel to it while being very puzzle like in the builds. It currently has 35 different challenge senarios that all have randomly generated buildings and ingredients with randomly generated possitives and negitives each time you start a new challenge so you can very much play the same challenge over and over and get an entirely different play through each and every time. The machines mechanics are for the most part well expained though there are some things that you learn by just doing. And say you don't like any of the scenarios or have beaten the master rank (basicly gold in a gold/silver/bronze rating system) of all the scenarios (which would take a long time to do even if your great at the game)  custom game has a ton of customization to it, choose anywhere from 0-3 competitors, 5-15 randomly generated ingredients, where you start with 2-5, how many catilist there are and their side effects, victory conditions of total revenue, operating profit, within x years, x products with atleast x profit or value or level, minimun cure rating, total products, and pay off loan, which you can combine in any fation, so say you want the winning condition to be where you have to have 3 pills that all make atleast $1,000 profit per pill produced all with atleast B cure rating within 15 years with no competitors, you can do that. You can also set what research you (and all competitors) start with and even what research is disabled in the game (so say you don't want anybody to be able to make patents you can disable patents).Then you get into settings like map size, event frequency, loan interest rates, plot cost, research speed, scientist saleries, scientiest hire cost, explorer saleries and hire costs, analyzing speed, patent speed, patent cost, cure market size, cure profit margins, starting money, starting loan, ingredient prices, process costs, build costs, research point accrual speed, ingredient point accrual speed, cure rate, infection rate... and all of these things don't have just like 5 settings, they are all sliders that have many many settings even if its not good at informing that well (for example plot cost you could set to where it says low and the first land may cost $500, but then you set it again in low but slightly in a different slider cost and now it costs $480 or $620 for the first one.Between the randomly generated buildings, the randomly generated ingredients, the number of custom challenges with 3 ratings that are fairly challenging to get the best rank on, and the sheer customability of custom games, you will find that this game is very replayable even doing the same challenge or even same custom game settings because even with the exact same custom settings the buildings and ingredients are randomly generated each time which also means what the competitors make which effects your profit margins also changes each time. And can be as challenging or easy as you want it to be. And even as quick or long as you want it to be depending on how you set all the custom game sliders and victory conditions.
