number of helpful: 6 of 11 people (55%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 3, 2015
												This is a clever little simulation game. The challenge comes in two forms. The first is a business management simulation, not unlike Theme Hospital or similar games. The second part of the game is a spacial puzzle. It starts out simply enough. Very simple production lines bring ingredients in and pump packaged drugs out with a few steps along the way to prepare the formula. As you progress in the game you will unlock many new ingredients and cures and technology used to prepare them.Initially, the game only offers you selections that are available at the current level. As such, the game appears quite basic on the surface for the first dozen or so scenarios. As you progress further in to the game, however, you unlock a great deal of new research projects and technology.Many of the negative reviews I am seeing for the game (not all, but many) are suggesting the game is very basic and has a short lifespan. These same reviews were mostly written by players who had between 2 and 6 hours of play time recorded. I suspect most of these players didn't even play long enough to see how much added complexity there is when you unlock patents and stage 4 cures, etc.Highly recommended to programmers or anyone who enjoys optimizing engines. The production line component of the is reminiscent of SpaceChem.

number of helpful: 5 of 9 people (56%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 1, 2016
												I don't like puzzle games. That's my story and I'm sticking to it. I bought this game because it's a business management simulator. Thing is, the business management part is only half of it, if that. The restf is very much a puzzle game, but not one that requires you to go so in depth with your puzzle solving thinking that you end up with a migraine.When playing Big Pharma, you'll notice that most of your time is spent, with the game paused, trying to fit equipment into spaces that make it work well with other equipment, within the constraints of the sometimes awkwardly shaped space provided. Sometimes you'll find yourself thinking "Geez, they must have made this chain of machines incompatible with this dumb building on purpose", while at other times you'll think "Wow, this fits so perfectly here, without wasting any space at all, that I must be doing something right!" Odds are pretty good that the reality is somewhere in the middle, where there wasn't much thought put into it at all aside from using the shapes of the buildings to throttle the difficulty. You will be annoyed at the lack of space, irritated with the AI for seeming to be able to patent something just as you're ramping up to produce it, but overall, you will get a sense of strange euphoria, seeing your machinations chug along, making you lots of money -- and it is pretty darn easy to make lots of money in this game. That part isn't hard. The difficulty definitely comes from making the pieces fit in a way that accomplishes your goals, effeciently and on timie, without blocking you from making the next line. This is a great game to play with the background music turned off and your favorite tunes playing instead. That's not to say that the background music is bad. It's just mediocre, and mostly pointless. The graphics look exactly like they should for a game such as this -- good enough. They're not realistic but they're not so cartoony as to be a distraction from the puzzle aspects.There is no story or campaign or anything. The closest you get is the "challenges" screen, which is the first thing you see when you click "New Game", and offers various scenarios with challenges attached. There is a tutorial which is both easy to use and fairly comprehensive, though you'll probably have to Google some of the higher tier equipment to see how they work. The information is not hard to find, though, so that's not really a downside. Overall, Big Pharma is a pretty good game. The simplicity will draw you in and keep you hooked even well past the point where you're tired of doing the same things over and over again and, really, that's its biggest rub -- redundancy. From the moment you play the first game in the "Beginner" column to the moment you put it away, you're doing pretty much the same thing over and over again. Think about it as an assembly line simulation tied in with some simplified business management concepts and you've got a good idea of what Big Pharma is all about.You're simply placing machines in a way that will be as efficient as you can make them. Everything else is just details. Is that a bad thing? In this case, I don't think it is. To me, the repitition gave me a sense of comfort, knowing that, at the beginning of every scenario, I had at least some *idea* of what I was doing. The first level drugs are extremely easy to make, and they get you off the ground pretty quickly, though you are forced to get more complicated since you'll oversaturate the market with them if you just make those. It was when the idea of starting fresh became significantly more appealing than continuing to try and get Master Level of accomplishment at a scenario that I realized it was probably time to play something else. However, that was 80 hours in, which is not a bad return for a game that costs $25 when it's not on sale! I'll probably go back to it at some point, too.

content:
Posted: August 27, 2015
												I jumped onto this while it was in beta and fell in love, I am happy to see it reach full release and look forward to play it again in a finished state.This is kind of an unique game, it kinda is a tycoon game were you build production lines to create and sell drugs while also search for new ingredients and do research for more options and better machinery. The production line building is more like a puzzler were the challenge lies to make a space efficient and use a minimal amount of machines to reach your goals.The ingredients you use have 4 "slots"  on them each with 1 curing effect and also 1-3 negative effects, stacked into the negative effects are also catalysts that are required for many cures to be upgraded. To top that off the ingredients also have a concentration wich ranges from 0-20 and different effects (both good and bad) are active at different concentration levels.Altough the concept of the game is quite easy to understand, it can get quite complex as you advance and need to mix and match different ingredients while trying optimse the concentration levels for upgrades while simultaniously trying to run a full speed production with a minimal amount of machines usage for your super drugs. All this is done on limited space and "sockets" that you need to bring in ingredients and ship out the drugs.The machines you use "never fits" wich adds a great deal of challenge while also giving a glorious feel of accomplishment once the line for your anaesthetic that cure aids, alzheimers and functions as a male contraceptive.I highly recommend this game

number of helpful: 11 of 21 people (52%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 27, 2015
												Don't be fooled by the hours played, I've put in at least 30 hours in the beta phase (outside steam).The good: Solid gameplay, in depth strategy combined with tactical considerations like space and use of import/export sockets, excellent replayability with custom level builder and sandbox modeAwesome graphics, animations and perfectly suited music. Watching your factory and drugs in motion is mesmerizing!Smoothest beta process I've ever been part of, very few bugs (personally never encountered any) and quick releaseNo 'missing' features that gamers are forced to pay again for in the form of DLC or add-ons. The game is complete on release.The bad:Umm maybe a bit difficult for new players to grasp? It's honestly not a difficult game but it's definitely a step up from the mindless clicking that most casual games ask for these days.As I was typing this I realized that expecting a game dev to put out a polished, feature complete game at release has become somewhat of a high expectation in the industry :( Big Pharma definitely meets it and then some! I do hope there may be some sort of expansion/sequel in the future but this is certainly not a game that is lacking content. Like the good old tycoon/city builder games of the 90s, Big Pharma doesn't hold your hand. Understanding the mechanics takes all of an hour or so but mastering the game is not so easy!I'd recommned this game to tycoon fans, puzzle fans and those that like to relax with their games.

number of helpful: 16 of 31 people (52%) found this review helpful3 people found this review funny
content:
Posted: November 30, 2015
 This key was obtained from the developer for review purposes. Summary: A surprisingly deep experience in the strategy genre. The game hits you over the head with the options for the custom game. Granted, it'll take a bit of time to understand all the elements the game, and the tutorial could be better at teaching you the game's elements. But once you get an understanding of everything the game has to offer, you'll find surprising depth. The game's strategy design is where it shines: what elements are adjustable and ones that are not are done with purpose and reason in my opinion. Dealing with competitors that actually can affect your gameplay in slight and even more direct ways was fun, and it made me a bit sad that there's no MP element of the game, as I really felt like the game could have truly shined there. When it comes down to it: I felt this game did something that I feel a lot of developers could learn from: start with a great base design, add the options later on, and designed it from the player's angle: and what they'd want. Rather impressed in the long run, and can recommend to strategy gamers out there. Gameplay Footage and Video Review: 


YouTube™ Video: Big Pharma (Critical Eye): Cures at your Local Poke Center 

			Views: 168		

			How does one exploit medicine? ALL THE PROFITS. ALL OF THEM. This key was obtained from the developer for review purposes.		

  Lists: +: Lots of customization options in terms of gameplay, and in particular with the custom game. Really can change the elements down to the most specific growth rates and research trees that are available. A lot of strategy games can learn from this level of customization. I cover strategy games rarely because of the type of player that I am (I'm the builder type, basically consider me the opposite of the zerg play style), but this game was right up my alley in terms of my game style, but other game styles as well.  Good balance of gameplay elements that don't overly punish you for not using them, but reward you for taking advantage of them. Cost vs effectiveness of the drug does make a difference, especially in the early going, but both strategies can be viable. Found that it stood the test of time in terms of variety with the smaller elements. Despite me restarting a lot due to my own personal weaknesses (aka wanting to perfect situations and so repeatedly starting again), I still found myself having fun.  This may seem weird to say, but some of the elements that you'd expect that aren't there (like setting the price of the drug) Actually like the restricted playing fields. Causes you to have your own puzzle mini-game regarding machine placement that works rather well.  Did I mention there's a good selection of options? There's a good selection of options.  There's apparently mod support. That's always a plus. -: Takes a bit of time to get going in terms of understanding. Lots of information to digest, and it could have been passed on to the player easier in the end. Tutorial could have been done better. Little rough around some of the edges. In particular with things like the belt controls feel like that there may have been a better implementation. Luckily, it's something that you can easily get adjusted to in time.  Would have loved to see a MP version of the game, but understand the development costs that would be required in order for that to happen.

content:
Posted: August 30, 2015
												Big Pharma is a great game for everyone who likes planning, tweaking, optimization. Your task is to manage a pharma corporation by producing and selling drugs. To get the job done, you´ll find your self searching for the required ingredients that can be processed and transformed into almost endless varieties as you increase or decrease concentration, add ingredients to produce new treatments and upgrade their effects. To make things more difficult, almost all ingredients have side effects that you may remove, weaken, avoid (by manipulating concentration) or just accept as a necessary evil - but beware, strong side effects will lower your drug rating and value. To make matters more complicated, your factory equipment cannot be placed neatly into straight assembly lines - each machine type has its own layout and creating complex chains will indeed be a puzzle game. And things usually don´t stay in place once you add new options to your arsenal - I find myself frequently redesigning my factory layout to optimize it according to the newly unlocked machines (which you can research). All the while, different scenarios and settings require you to work towards a variety of different objectives, from just making cash to delivering a super-drug with high value.To sum it up:  This game makes you think! If you like complex problem solving tasks, this is definitely your game.

number of helpful: 2 of 4 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 30, 2015
												I'll say this is one mind bending game.Cons first:  First the interface does need a touch up.  The GUI needs work to help navigate from cure start to cure finish along the lines of what you need to do.  At the moment you constantly have to switch between tabs in the GUI to determine the proper course of action to produce your product, fortunately you can pause the game.  It is a bit tedious to do so and I would like to see something more streamlined that allows for easier production of your cure.Second, No multiplayer.  You do play against an AI.  The AI's production of similar products  will effect cure pricing and both you and the AI can issue patents to have sole ownership of a cure.  There are world events that dictate supply and demand so it would be great to have multiplayer for the same reasons.  Unfortunately in a multiplayer scenario there would have to be two requirements:  A: Make it turn based to get around the GUI issue, or B: streamline the GUI for faster recognition of steps.That's it for cons that I see.Pros:Game runs very well.  The GUI does look great.  You really feel like a factory floor manager.Nice graphics.  Everything moves flawlessly around your factory floor going from starting point to A>B>C>D>E sell (Sometimes more steps, sometimes less).The game has an awesome puzzle base to it.  Not only must you solve on how to make your cures effective while mitigating side effects but you must also work out factory logistics to make your factory run efficiently.  Getting things to run efficiently is the harder part in my opinion, since you can pause the game to research your cure development steps.  Modable, no need to say more.All in all I really enjoy it.  It has the right amout of difficulty to frustrate the hell out of you and make you want to come back over and over to try to solve that pesky logistical problem so you can make as much money as possible.  Believe me I have quit several times in my short play time to give my mind the time to solve the problems while not actually sitting and playing.  Damn you money, I want more.

number of helpful: 7 of 15 people (47%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 27, 2015
												I've been playing Big Pharma via a non-Steam version and have been really enjoying it. I'd played at least a dozen hours before the 1.0 release and have been very please with how the developer has not only been regularly updating the game, but also responding to community inputs and making changes based on them.I'd have to say that it's partly a puzzle game, in that you have to build assembly lines that require some planning and tinkering to fit them in the available space and also to spend as little money as possible. And you have to research more efficient (abet more costly) production machines that take up less space.It's also a business sim, in that you buy resourses, process them and then produce a product. This is done very well in the game because you don't have to stare at spreadsheets, instead you can just mouse over the production lines or your company page and the appropriate info is right there. And it's very easy to understand where you are making and losing money, in fact I'd say that this game is one of the best examples of how to make a business sim right.And the other nice feature that I like is that the game is composed of a number of scenarios/missions, most of which have three different levels of victory, and you don't have to unlock any particular mission to play any other of them. Plus there's also a custom game mode, where you can alter all sorts of criteria and conditions, and a free build mode where you can just make assembly lines and geek out on that.The game is very polished and glitch and bug free. I very much recommend it.

content:
Posted: January 20
												Big Pharma isn't a bad game, but I just didn't have much fun with it. It seems like a game designed for someone who is a little OCD and enjoys the process of meticulously optimizing a production line. For me, the game kept me engaged but felt more like work than fun.Pros:+ The game looks good and is pretty polished.+ The mechanics are fine and sensible. The game is very playable.+ The game does require a lot of strategy. There is a definite puzzle element that might appeal to some people.Cons:- If you want to go beyond simple competence in the game, it requires some heavy-duty number crunching and space optimization. This feels like a game where the right way to play it would involve lots of spreadsheets and things.- The game lacks a story or structure to keep it engaging. You work hard to meet a meaningless goal. Then, once you finally beat a level, your work was for nothing and you just go to the next level--which is pretty much the same as the one before it. I did not find the payoff for my hard work to be worth it.

number of helpful: 3 of 7 people (43%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 23, 2016
												Big Pharma is a very refreshing take on factory building that offers genuine satisfaction for coming up with the best production line you can think of.  Where similar games get by overloading with content and chaos--more things to build, higher volume, etc, Big Pharma rewards for elegant solutions.  It isn't about how much you produce.  It's about how you produce it.For simplicity's sake, I will contrast Big Pharma with Factorio, which I also got a lot of enjoyment from.  Factorio is about managing resources and logistics--incredibly large numbers of exceedingly simple tasks that combine to create hectic situations.  The entire game (Factorio) can be summed up as deciding what you want to make, then ensuring the right buildings are getting the right amounts of all requisite materials in a massive and complicated chain involving dozens of buildings.  All gameplay revolves around that.Big Pharma is absolutely nothing like that; rather, it is about design and decision making.  Where Factorio gets complicated, Big Pharma is merely complex.  In Big Pharma, you can make whatever sort of cure you like.  Expensive or cheap, whether you earn or lose money is determined by *how* you chose to make the product and whether it was a wise choice to make it at all considering demand, competition, and your current capabilities.  You can make crazy wonder drugs and lose money with a hasty production line a la Factorio, or you can put some thought into it and make millions.  The same applies to the cheap drugs.  Maybe you even allow a minor, negative side effect in the product to ensure economic viability.  It's up to you to determine what the right move is, and when you make that right move, you get genuine satisfaction out of it that games like Factorio are simply incapable of matching.I am not saying that Big Pharma is better than Factorio.  I got a lot more time out of Factorio than I did from Big Pharma.  But I do believe the time I spent with Big Pharma was more enjoyable and satisfying, which is quite fitting.  Production in Factorio is all about volume, and production in Big Pharma is all about quality and substance.  This mirrors my gameplay experience with the two games quite nicely.

content:
Posted: August 30, 2015
												I  was hoping this would be a lot like Free Enterprise, only without the glitches. However, it is far more puzzle heavy than sim/strategy/management. Even if it had the charm of the luggage converyor game in the Let's Explore The Airport with Buzzy children's game of yester year, it would have been okay. As is, it leaves a bit to be desired. Cons:- Conveyor belt routing is a time waster, but not totally miserable.- Initially have to reference a fair amount of material hoping back and forth between tabs, making it more like work than a game.- Once you memorize the tech tree and how the different components work, it becomes a logic/routing/adding/subtracting exercise. It isn't what I think of when I think sim/strategy/management. I feel like it is a tad mislabeled.- The tutorial is rather important, but is a text walkthrough at the moment.....Pros:  - If you like time sensitive puzzles, this is a great game. - If you are looking for logic/spacial reasoning work within the framework of a nice looking interface and overall "game-like" goals, this is a great choice. - The graphics are nice.  - The interface is usable and I have not run into any issues with it yet.I might want a good puzzle every now and then. However, enjoy playing it for hours on end I highly doubt.Recommend? Yes, as a puzzle game. As sim/strategy/management? Sorry, but no.

												This is a pretty neat game. Its a Puzzle/ Simulation game. It takes a bit to get used to even after playing the tutorial. It would cool if they incoporated other aspects of big pharma to the game like getting aproval for your products by the government or getting doctors to recomend your product to their patients. All this is is watching conveyor belts transport goods untill you figure out the right combo to succeed. That being said it is a nice unique game that im sure you can have a lot of fun with. Just watch some videos to see if its something you'll enjoy before impulse buying.

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 3, 2016
												A tycoon/simulator game where you build production lines for medicine. There is no story mode/campaign but rather many scenarios that require you to reach a certain objective (like a target revenue) within a time limit.You start with an open area and have to build production lines for medicine. You start with a vent on the wall to import raw ingredients, pass it through several processing machines to refine and produce the medicine, then end with a vent on the wall to export the completed product. There are a variety of machines and you'll have to make decisions on how to make your medicine. There are tradeoffs in space, manufacturing speed, profit, and quality of medicine based on which and how many machines you use. Also, there is a research system in place that requires you to invest money to eventually unlock more ingredients, machines, and other bonuses,Certain things could be better polished/presented:The tutorial could be better- it's just one long scrollable text box. I would've liked a tutorial that was properly divided into separate windows for each step and with UI focus (like highlighting/pointer arrows, etc.) on what is being talked about. It's not too hard to learn if you've played similar games or have a knack with understanding program UI but the tutorial could use some polishing up.At first glance it seemed that there were only 4 columns of challenges but one day I was surprised when my mouse cursor wandered to the right edge of the screen and it scrolled a little. There's no reason to move your mouse all the way to the right (you can hover over the right-most challenges without scrolling the screen)Sometimes it's hard to click on a specific thing (like vents to change ingredients or to delete specific tiles of that are partially hidden behind things). It's due to perspective but there has to be some way to better select objects in the back. You have to click on a certain area for vents that you'll have to learn by experience.There are a couple UI changes I would have liked:To have a dedicated area to see current active events. I couldn't find the details anywhere after I dismissed the event box. After a while you can manually check the graphs for the changes but it would still be a nice addition.To toggle ingredient icons while zoomed out (normally, all icons disappear). I liked to use the icons to figure out which areas are making which product (which is useful when you want to change production).To find the location of your product line by clicking on the product in your company tabTo display the amount of ingredient currently being used in the upgrade tooltip (like the machine upgrade tooltip). This would let you know at a glance which ingredient you're using a lot (so how much the upgrade would benefit you).'Auto pause and focus' is nice but it will sometimes not work if you've currently opened another event window. Your product line (and its revenue) will stop completely while it waits for you to name a product so the product naming window should really always pause and force you to deal with it (Or the product should keep selling under the generic name until you name it).Personally, I would've liked a campaign or scenarios with personalities and scripted events to make things interesting. A little story to link things together helps keep my interest when doing multiple playthroughs of the same thing. The sandbox is fun for a while but it's not like The Sims where it's easy to make your own story in the sandbox. I had fun doing a few challenges and then went straight to a custom game with all tier levels unlocked to get the full experience.Worth a look if you like sandbox tycoon games and refining your strategy through multiple playthroughs.

content:
Posted: January 1
												I will review all my humble bundle games and see which is worth playing and which is not! Like a lot of people i buy H.B. games as a pack because i want some of the games, but not all. I will play for 5 minutes (or a little bit more) and give you my opinion on it. Sometimes the game will surprise me, sometimes it will be a total disappointment. Just keep in mind this is my opinion only and is not an objective view of the game. You might actually like it!The review will be constructed into 5 parts:1. Game description (from what I’ve seen in the time I’ve played).2. Did i finish the game (YES/NO/Maybe in the future) and why.3. Pros/Cons.4. Final thoughts.5. RatingSo let's begin...1. Game description:When I started this game I had expected something like Roller coaster tycoon(what I think a management game should be) but with medical drugs. I was so wrong. The graphics are on par for a management game. Nothing too special but not bad. Music and sound effects are ok and the gameplay is…well OK too. It’s nothing special and definitely not what I expected, but it’s OK for what it does. However the building part doesn’t matter too much and that’s what killed it for me. It’s a micromanagement decision making game, with a little construction thrown in.2. Did i finish the game? NOThe fact that the building portion of the game was so small made me uninstall it after the first mission. I don’t think I will be coming back to this one.3. Pros/Cons.PROS:- A pretty good management gameCONS:- Not a lot of building in it4. Final thoughts:Not my style of management game, although a lot of people will enjoy it. 5. Rating6/10

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 21
												In general, I like Big Pharma, and have had fun completing some of the various challenges. The initial puzzle solving is interesting, and I enjoy trying to create the perfect drug in the space allotted. I also very much like that it is pauseable real-time, so that I can take as long as I want figuring things out.However, the game is very similar each play-through, with only minor randomness (the floor layout and the ingredients list are all that change). So once you know what works, it pretty much works every time. The computer opponents are also not so much competitors as a nuisance, as they cannot beat you, but only get in your way. The only thing you are really fighting against is the clock, and your own goals.So while I think this game is good for people who like puzzle and optimization games, it is not for everyone, I am not sure it is worth the full asking price. So if this looks interesting to you, watch for a good sale and give it a try.

												I picked this up on a big sale. It's probably not worth $28, but $14 sure. It's worth a good 15-20 hours of gameplay. The most frustrating thing is how difficult and finnicky it is to setup multi-feed processes. Like mixers take 2 turns to process when many other processes take 1; so you should have 2 mixers - but this becomes so burdensome to try and setup that you will quit and take the 50% slower process. There should be some kind of simple "belt programming" so I can say "belt intersection alternates firing left then right" instead of constantly trying to delete, play, delete, play, delete play; to try and time my ingredients correctly and then STILL the belts will fire in the right direction, then the wrong again. AHH! Game is a cool concept, fun to play, but a completionist/perfectionist will go mental.

Posted: January 4
												I was a little bit wary about this game when I first got it, but oh boy, was I pleasantly surprised! This game is positively addicting, and it has tons of fun challenges to keep you occupied for hours and hours! Definitely recommend it if you like simulation games, it has a bit of a learning curve, but once you get past it you'll have fun designing intricate assembly lines for hours. Not the most complicated in terms of what you can actually do, but still plenty charming and fun!The one gripe I have with this game is that the interface is a little bit unintuitive. I think they were going for a kind of minimalist thing, but it'd be much nicer if my eyes didn't have to scan past inches and inches of blank space to find what I needed to see. It'd be cool if they put the Production tab and the Ingredients tab into one interface, because it feels kind of bloated otherwise. Still, a very minor criticism for an otherwise fun and addictive game!

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 9, 2016
												See what it feels like to be Martin Shkreli, in this pharmaceutical company management sim, ... well maybe not. In Big Pharma you do manage a pharmaceutical company but it's more of a puzzle game with management elements. Big part of the gameplay is placing various machines that increase or decrease concentration of ingredients or mix them up and finally turn them into pills or creams or syringes. All these machines have different input and output locations and often sizes, you also need to add conveyor belts and with limited amount of space and doors through which ingredients can enter and leave your factory creating a new drug becomes, well a puzzle. Besides planning your factory you'll send explorers in search of new ingredients and researchers to invent new types of machines or improve existing ones. You can play in free mode or one of many challenges. What is really smart and should be adopted in other games is that the challenges get progressively more complex. And I don't mean that the competition gets tougher or you are hit with arbitrary debuffs. The game actually limits your research tree and ingredient list to only present you with simple choices. Then as you progress you are given more and more options. It's a really nice game that hits that improvement itch, you've created a cure for bad breath and now you can improve it and cure sore throat. Coming up with more and more complex recipes for more advanced cures is extremely satisfying. Dad rating: ExcellentGame can be paused at any time, giving you time to attend to the little ones. Speed can also be increased if you prefer to breeze through the more boring periods.No violence what so ever. No scary monsters jumping out on the screen either. You can safely play it with your child on your knees.I highly recommend it my 10h with Big Pharma felt like a breeze and I'm looking forward to many more.

content:
Posted: December 24, 2016
												Overall, great idea and solid presentation. It's really a lot of fun to build assembly lines, and to create the final product. The learning curve is a bit steep at first, but plateaus very rapidly once you figure out the couple more advanced concepts and techniques.As fun as it is to play, the one thing I fault this game with is the use of "Challenges" as the core game mode format; which I found to not be that engaging.This might work well for 'completionist' type players who want to achieve the highest rating for each Challenge, but I think Big Pharma would really benefit from a Civilization-type approach where you build a drug empire, interact directly with other AI Pharmaceutical companies in different ways (hostile takeovers, mergers, forcing them out of business, etc...) and strive to achieve one of multiple possible victory types, all over a fairly long period of time. Overall, definitely worth the price, but this game could be so much more with a bit more gameplay depth.

content:

												I will review all my humble bundle games and see which is worth playing and which is not! Like a lot of people i buy H.B. games as a pack because i want some of the games, but not all. I will play for 5 minutes (or a little bit more) and give you my opinion on it. Sometimes the game will surprise me, sometimes it will be a total disappointment. Just keep in mind this is my opinion only and is not an objective view of the game. You might actually like it!The review will be constructed into 5 parts:1. Game description (from what I’ve seen in the time I’ve played).2. Did i finish the game (YES/NO/Maybe in the future) and why.3. Pros/Cons.4. Final thoughts.5. RatingSo let's begin...1. Game description:When I started this game I had expected something like Roller coaster tycoon(what I think a management game should be) but with medical drugs. I was so wrong. The graphics are on par for a management game. Nothing too special but not bad. Music and sound effects are ok and the gameplay is…well OK too. It’s nothing special and definitely not what I expected, but it’s OK for what it does. However the building part doesn’t matter too much and that’s what killed it for me. It’s a micromanagement decision making game, with a little construction thrown in.2. Did i finish the game? NOThe fact that the building portion of the game was so small made me uninstall it after the first mission. I don’t think I will be coming back to this one.3. Pros/Cons.PROS:- A pretty good management gameCONS:- Not a lot of building in it4. Final thoughts:Not my style of management game, although a lot of people will enjoy it. 5. Rating6/10

												A very comprehensive management/simulation/factory game that requires a lot of strategy, not only from a floor space perspective, but also for optimization of processes, a degree of cost/benefit analysis, workforce management, and some degree of business sense to be successful at the Expert level (Middle level).  I've really enjoyed this game, can't wait to continue with it, and can't wait to see what changes with it in the future.

content:
Posted: January 21
												In general, I like Big Pharma, and have had fun completing some of the various challenges. The initial puzzle solving is interesting, and I enjoy trying to create the perfect drug in the space allotted. I also very much like that it is pauseable real-time, so that I can take as long as I want figuring things out.However, the game is very similar each play-through, with only minor randomness (the floor layout and the ingredients list are all that change). So once you know what works, it pretty much works every time. The computer opponents are also not so much competitors as a nuisance, as they cannot beat you, but only get in your way. The only thing you are really fighting against is the clock, and your own goals.So while I think this game is good for people who like puzzle and optimization games, it is not for everyone, I am not sure it is worth the full asking price. So if this looks interesting to you, watch for a good sale and give it a try.

content:
Posted: February 9, 2016
												See what it feels like to be Martin Shkreli, in this pharmaceutical company management sim, ... well maybe not. In Big Pharma you do manage a pharmaceutical company but it's more of a puzzle game with management elements. Big part of the gameplay is placing various machines that increase or decrease concentration of ingredients or mix them up and finally turn them into pills or creams or syringes. All these machines have different input and output locations and often sizes, you also need to add conveyor belts and with limited amount of space and doors through which ingredients can enter and leave your factory creating a new drug becomes, well a puzzle. Besides planning your factory you'll send explorers in search of new ingredients and researchers to invent new types of machines or improve existing ones. You can play in free mode or one of many challenges. What is really smart and should be adopted in other games is that the challenges get progressively more complex. And I don't mean that the competition gets tougher or you are hit with arbitrary debuffs. The game actually limits your research tree and ingredient list to only present you with simple choices. Then as you progress you are given more and more options. It's a really nice game that hits that improvement itch, you've created a cure for bad breath and now you can improve it and cure sore throat. Coming up with more and more complex recipes for more advanced cures is extremely satisfying. Dad rating: ExcellentGame can be paused at any time, giving you time to attend to the little ones. Speed can also be increased if you prefer to breeze through the more boring periods.No violence what so ever. No scary monsters jumping out on the screen either. You can safely play it with your child on your knees.I highly recommend it my 10h with Big Pharma felt like a breeze and I'm looking forward to many more.

content:
Posted: August 28, 2015
												So first off: this game has a lot of polish. this is a well-done game.  the UI is slick, the mechanics are new (to me) and interesting.maybe I'm being too picky, but I take umberage with how they implemented the belts - and for a game that hinges on logistics, belts are important. they have frustrating logic, trying to 'predict' your intentions. Basically you should only be placing belts as the final step, and even then dragging from point A to B is the most efficent path, but not if you want to tuck into that space later - also if you're in a rush, you're more likely to place a t-junction that halts an entire  production line, and there is no attention grabbing 'hey you broke x'. I apologize for offering criticism without an alternative, but all I can think of is more fine-grained control.if you like a good puzzle game / business sim with some depth (the ingredients and researching and upgrades are a nice touch) and don't mind looking past some frusting flaws (or are more forgiving/patient than I) then this could be hours of enjoyment for you.as it is, 20$ for a game that will end with ME needing blood pressure medication? I'll pass.

content:
Posted: May 7, 2016
												Buggy game.Imagine you have a really efficient system, and a nice long machine, connecting each part to another in perfect harmony. You then add a machine that slows down the process slightly, and although you're limited by space, you see a small opportunity to add in another machine to help increase profits.You spend the last of your money getting everything in place, then connect it all with belts. Suddenly, everything but your new addition grinds to a halt, as it turns out one of the belts in the new T-junction you've created is trying to move in the opposite direction.You scratch your head, thinking "but there's an input and an output... why can't it see which way to go? Everntually, you contact the developer, who says "It's literally impossible to fix this"... You then realise that the developer simply doesn't know how to fix this bug, and therefore calls it a feature, telling people not to use T-Junctions, even though they limit the space provided, and encourage you to connect machines together and utlise space as best as possible.It's a nice game, and certainly a time sink, but whomever designed the belts system needs to go back and do them again. Especially as they're the most used object in the game.It's not going to happen though... as the developer refuses to admit there's a problem, despite the number of people arguing their point.For that reason alone, it's not recommended. You'll find yourselves more frustrated than entertained.

number of helpful: 8 of 19 people (42%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 30, 2015
												Big Pharma is essentially a game where you are able to spend your money on parts such as "evaporators" and "dissolvers" in order to create new medications that will essentially give you more money, to spend more parts, to get more money, to spend new parts etc. This game has an endless cycle of "spending money on parts" and "gaining more money", just like the games "Rollercoaster Tycoon" and "Holy Potatoes! A Weapon Shop?". Other than giving specific goals to reach, such as gaining $1,000,000 in revenue in 10 years, this game really has no point other than to keep you in the "endless cycle", which is why I cannot give it a "thumbs up".However, If you are the type of person who loves these kinds of games, then I will tell you that there are many aspects to consider, including:-Research-Finding new Ingredients-Getting Loans when your bankrupt (which many games do not allow you to do)-Upgrading standard Migraine Pills to something even better-Upgrading Equipment-Competitor Companies (AI companies, not multiplayer)Even though Big Pharma is not my preferred cup of tea, it may be of interest to people who like the game I just described above.Happy Gaming-Matt

content:
Posted: April 29, 2016
												I bought this game for 5 bucks. Thought it was a steal but I still ended up asking for a refund. Now I cannot say that all will share my experience. But this game was far too complex for me. I got frustrated playing the tutorial. A tutorial which encouraged me to create the requested result "In my own way." to just "make sure the end result is the same." I did this several times throughout my 4 hour playtime. Eventually I gave in and just copied exactly as it was in the pictures (as far as layout) and what do you know, It worked. However, the end resulting drug that was created was the EXACT same drug I created with my layout. As I stated in the begining, this may just be my own fault. This game may be too smart for me. But I feel that if your tutorial contains grammatical errors and lack luster instructions to say the least, it makes it a bad time universally. To its credit, it's very robust. Tons of scenarios and modes to play with. It's just that the game is not fun.

content:
Posted: August 28, 2015
												Not much of a tycoon game, more of a puzzle game. I found it very confusing, and not fun. It kind of reminds me of a cross between Pipe Dreams and The Incredible Machine. I'm not really much of a fan of puzzle games in general, and I almost flunked Chemistry in high school. This game doesn't really do it for me.But if you're looking for something really tricky and complicated with hundreds of moving parts, you'd probably like it. I was hoping for more management / business type stuff and there are elements of that here, but the main goal is to figure out how to make X, Y, and Z by combining A with B, then adding some S and P, subtracting N, performing the square root of J and inputting that as the coefficient of C to get D.

content:
Posted: December 1, 2015
												This game has a very interesting concept, balancing both business simulation and logistics planning, making this one of the deepest and most challenging tycoon game yet. The random generation also allows for more challenging scenarios and replayability, but is also one of the downsides to the game, considering business simulation and RNG tend to dislike each other. I'm not far through the game yet, but it is starting to get repetitive, as most missions can be completed by the same general business strategy of "upgrade and expand as much as possible". Controls, UI, and other gameplay elements are handled well, so there's not much to say about that. Rating:7/10 Not a bad game at all, but I suggest getting it for a lower price due to the repetitive nature of its gameplay.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: December 1, 2015
												It's easy to see that the developers have tried hard to make a good game based on a new idea. And they have gone 95% of the way, but the games still feels like a beta version of the real game. The controls are clumsy: you move around with the same right button as you sell; switching between tabs takes so much time, although you do it all the time; I still try to push escape to get to the main view (because it's natural!), but only get to the menu; the default building hotekys are on the numeric keyboard (do you think everyone has it?) and I still haven't found a hotkey for belts.At the same time, the gameprocess is overloaded by messages and different areas in which your attention is required, which doesn't let you focus on something in particular, but always distracts you. The analysis of market is not well presented, so it's hard to understand what is the best course of action at the moment. Finally, fitting your equipment in the factory is interesting the first two minutes, but then you are kind of tired playing tetris and are more interested in concentrating on more important stuff, but nope, you cannot. And if you want to double your production you cannot copy a segment of your conveyor, but have to rebuild it againg with all the connections, which feels like a complete loss of time.This game is a good try and may become something good in the end, but for the moment it is largely overpriced (I wouldn't pay more than 5$ for it) and in my opinion needs large sales and an army of beta-testers to make it playable for more than two hours. So be aware: for the moment this game is not what you expect. But it still has a change to become a good one.

content:
Posted: March 23, 2016
												This game is beyond amazing. If you love strategy and management games with oddly satisfying graphics and sounds, this is the game for you! This game is a mashup of many different game types. Management? You can macro or miro manage your entire company. Strategy? The game has thousands of different types of drugs you can make. Puzzle? Find out how to make all of your drugs side-effect free and leveled up the highest. There is something for everyone in this game!

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: May 14, 2016
												I've had Big Pharma for a while now; I bought it when it wasn't on steam (A few months before the release) and have gotten a pretty solid idea on the game.Graphics: Simple 2nd Dimensional, isometric camera view. All the machines have nice animations, and the customization of your building, albeit basic with flooring and wall paper, add a bit of hominess and individuality to your lines.Sound: Not much to say. The music is nice and the sound effects are good, but far from breaking any records. Gameplay: Big Pharma is a building game, a puzzle game, and a business management game. You pick "play" and you are presented with a wide varity of missions. These range from "produce X amount of treatment for X" to "Make a profit of X dollars." What is great is that you are able to approach this however you want; the game doesn't force you to follow specific paths. You get to build whatever manufacturing lines you'd like to produce medications. It gives a feeling of freedom, compared to other games where they hold your hand and demand you do things in a certain order, and more or less penalize you for differentiating. Each effect requires a bevy of actions first. To get treatment for X, first you must set the concentration to the right values with machines like the evaporator and ioniser. You may need to combine it with a catalyst effect- Which comes with other symptoms too, so you have to figure out what to do with the biproduct too. Along with keeping a functioning line running, you need to keep a mind for space conservation- each exspansion of your building takes money, and they aren't too roomy. Along with making sure your lines work and you have enough space, you need to keep an eye on your competitors; developed a wondercure for a very exspensive symptom? Soon, the AI competitors will rush to roll out those medications and steal some of your profits. Multi-tasking is a critical part of the game, and if you will have a bad time if you're only good at focusing one thing at a time. Another great feature is the hands-on tutorial. It lays down the foundation you need to understand the game and get a business running, but is entirely skippable if you chose.Overall, Big Pharma is a great game if you're into the business management economic simulator genre of games.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: May 2, 2016
												Big Pharma is a nice combination of puzzle solving, business simulation and floor planning. I have not come across any other game which manages to combine all these facets of gameplay and still remain interesting.The game offers you so many opportunities to optimize your designs, production layouts, pricing, research that I only seem to unpause the game when I run out of money. However, once you start making some serious money in a few years, you can just get caught up in designing the perfect drug for each disease and then creating the production layout for it in tight factory spaces. Some reviewers have mentioned that drug designing is a simple matter of increasing or decreasing the concentration but I think that those players have not yet discovered other aspects of drug designing which really compel you to look at all the possibilties and then create that Viagra-like drug that will change the world!The best part, perhaps, is that all these complexities offer value to those players who wish to indulge in them. If you just want to keep it simple, you can easily make enough money by just producing simple generic drugs.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: May 7, 2016
												A lot of fun for people who enjoy building and improving their "mousetraps" (which I greatly enjoy.)  The many challenges of the game are fun and rewarding to try and beat on Master level.  Good tutorial to help you jump in pretty quickly, a little heavy on the reading if you're not into that sort of thing, but if you're not, you're probably not gonna wanna play a drug-making simulator anyway.Marketing and Malpractice DLC added TREMENDOUS depth and enjoyability (and replayability) to the game.  Having a ton of fun with it.One of my most profitable drugs was in high demand, and cheap to make but had bad side effects.  When I tried to make it more helpful to the populace in general, it ended up being not as profitable and I had to chuckle about the irony of that compared to real life (something I think the game designers intended to represent.)  However my competitors started manufacturing better versions of the drug and stealing all my sales.  So naturally I did what every good pharma company would do: patented my crappy version so that they couldn't sell their (economic infeasible) versions and steal my sales.10/10 would make money at the expense of human health and well-being again

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: December 1, 2015
												It's easy to see that the developers have tried hard to make a good game based on a new idea. And they have gone 95% of the way, but the games still feels like a beta version of the real game. The controls are clumsy: you move around with the same right button as you sell; switching between tabs takes so much time, although you do it all the time; I still try to push escape to get to the main view (because it's natural!), but only get to the menu; the default building hotekys are on the numeric keyboard (do you think everyone has it?) and I still haven't found a hotkey for belts.At the same time, the gameprocess is overloaded by messages and different areas in which your attention is required, which doesn't let you focus on something in particular, but always distracts you. The analysis of market is not well presented, so it's hard to understand what is the best course of action at the moment. Finally, fitting your equipment in the factory is interesting the first two minutes, but then you are kind of tired playing tetris and are more interested in concentrating on more important stuff, but nope, you cannot. And if you want to double your production you cannot copy a segment of your conveyor, but have to rebuild it againg with all the connections, which feels like a complete loss of time.This game is a good try and may become something good in the end, but for the moment it is largely overpriced (I wouldn't pay more than 5$ for it) and in my opinion needs large sales and an army of beta-testers to make it playable for more than two hours. So be aware: for the moment this game is not what you expect. But it still has a change to become a good one.

												This game has a very interesting concept, balancing both business simulation and logistics planning, making this one of the deepest and most challenging tycoon game yet. The random generation also allows for more challenging scenarios and replayability, but is also one of the downsides to the game, considering business simulation and RNG tend to dislike each other. I'm not far through the game yet, but it is starting to get repetitive, as most missions can be completed by the same general business strategy of "upgrade and expand as much as possible". Controls, UI, and other gameplay elements are handled well, so there's not much to say about that. Rating:7/10 Not a bad game at all, but I suggest getting it for a lower price due to the repetitive nature of its gameplay.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: January 4, 2016
												This game is a unique blend of big-picture simulation and puzzle like supply chain management that I think anyone who likes sim or puzzle games should look into. I definitely recommend it on sale to a fan of either genre.  Otherwise, it is more of a niche game than I thought it would be, which makes it tough for me to recommend to the average gamer.  I followed this game since the first dev vlogs came out, then bought it in the beta phase, and for me there was just enough that the game did well that made it worth me supporting it before release.Pros:+ Supply Chain Management Tycoon: This is something unique that it does very well regarding drug creation/production. If you're not into Sim and Puzzle type games, then think twice before buying the game.+ Scenario Variety and Customization: Dozens of scenarios of varying difficulties with the ability to create your own.+ AI / Competition: I didn't find competing companies to be unrealistically hard or easy. With 3+ competitors, innovation to different drug types are imperative.+ Macro management (other than supply chain): Dev explicitly stated that the game wasn't designed for micro managing a pharmacy company. Big picture management is done well though with plenty of Research & Development opportunities, and it doesn't bog you down with price management or small stuff.+ Subtle ethical decisions: Some people wanted to be hit over the head with this, but again, it seemed secondary in the eyes of the dev. The decisions currently come in the form of...Do I leave this side effect or weak cure as is because my profit will be higher? Do I stop production on a drug that is still in demand just to move on to higher level cures with larger profits? Do I "research" corporate espionage in order to see my competitors' profit margins, etc?Cons:-Incentiveize the game play loop: There's 3 completion levels for each scenario indicating how well the player did, but that, scenario uniqueness, or making a specific type of drug (e.g. hair growing male enhancement drug) seems about it for replay motivation.-Starting drug RNG (may be fixed): I've read about a number of players restarting scenarios until their initial unlocked drug combo was ideal. This may be more of a player min/maxing issue, and I think a patch meant to address this, but I don't know how well this helped.-Micro management (by design): As mentioned above, the game wasn't designed for that, and this may bug some people. Just supply chain and big picture stuff is what is mostly in this game.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: February 25, 2016
												Big Pharma is a great little game in which you get to play as the big pharmaceutical companies, create drugs, sell them and build up reputation.The game is in essens a puzzle game with some light management thrown in for good measure. Most of the gameplay is creating drug chains that optimizes drugs (for profit or usefulness) and then to sell them. Which is really a really satisfying puzzle game. All of the machines that create drugs have a different shape and size and in order to fit them all in you either need to plan out what you'll need ahead of time, because moving production lines after they are completed is really difficult, alternatively you can buy smaller more effective machines, however those will crank up the production cost for the drug, directly affecting your bottom line.The game is great in that you can create really weird drugs that may or may not actually work, but after all it's all about making money and not drugs right? You will need to decide wheater you value space efficiency vs price, what research should you prioretize. All the while trying to stay ahead of the competition which have just patented your new drug formula rendering the giganormous production line you just created, worthless...It's a great little zen game where once in a while you sit back and just wait for your drugs' ratings go up or down, accumulate money etc. Contemplating weather or not it's the right time to expand, what you should expand into, is it worth optimizing that one cure so that its drug rating goes up...There's almost always something to do, at least in the beginning and then the game zens out after a while.One bad thing about the game however is that when you get to a sort of "critical mass" you basically cannot lose, except  for deadlines. There's not really too many challenges after the initial ones, because when you manage to get enough drugs to sell, you will start making tons of money and the game really turns into a fine tuning game. I'm not saying it isn't  fun at that point, but it really doesn't require as much baby sitting.On the other hand that might be exactly what you're looking for as you can then sit and maybe catch up on a series, Youtube etc.All in all, it's a nice little game, especially if you can get it in a sale, great if you need something to stimulate that gamer part of the brain as you catch up on videos or whatever. I for one can't just sit and do one thing at a time, so this is a great game for me. :)

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: February 20, 2016
												I played this game quite a bit in pre-Steam alpha - I recommend this game only to those who enjoy puzzle games, I'd say it's worth it if you can get it on sale for 10 bucks or less. If you are looking for a tycoon/management game, this is not it.------I was originally intrigued because it reminded me a bit of Theme Hospital, which - like most Bullfrog games, I loved - but this doesn't play like a tycoon game, or a management game. It's more of a puzzle game. Think Tetris where you have to research the different pieces. This game cries out for a sandbox mode... where you can build a room, build an import, layout your machinery, then build an export - use the funds to research/innovate/explore etc - enlarge your factory, add more production lines, make more money, stay ahead of the competition. Instead you get numerous scenarios in which you have to gain an arbitrary amount of money and/or create a specific type of medicine by a certain date and/or before the competiton. The game itself is that you fit your production line into a predetermined amount of space. The ingredients must be researched and require various amounts of machines (which must also be researched) to get them into medically effective states. Your work out the logistics to make it all fit. Rinse, repeat. Personally, I dislike scenario games like this; any game where I'm asked to spend time building something only to leave it all behind and start again from scratch level after level, wears thin on me rather quickly.That said, the game is extremely well made in terms of quality, the UI has been streamlined and overall it's very solid. This dev knows what they're doing, and I look forward to more of their work.

content:
Posted: November 12, 2016
												This is a puzzle/logistics game that dives into the economy/politics side of drug companies.  There are various challenges to complete, with different tiers of success, ensuring you will come back to previous challenges with more experience and a better outcome.  Some examples of challenges include, deliver 200 units of hair loss product (requiring desert research and follow-up exploration and an end-game atomic sequencer) before a set amount of time, produce 6 products with a B+ rating (you can make a few extra bucks if you don't process out side-effects, but this challenge requires you to find profitable and sustainable drugs without using questionable business practices), and make as much money as possible using patents, putting out as much product with as little work as possible, and undercutting the AI businesses as much as possible!This game's business side is a little light, but is expanded on in the very affordable DLC that add new layers to the game.  I would recommend getting the DLC, but only after you try the base game.  It isn't everyone's cup of tea, but it sure is mine!

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: May 16, 2016
												It's one of those games that you start over and over and over and over trying to make it better next time. Only to realize that, well, you won't. The theme of the game is, basically, building a pipeline from a start to a finish point with some machines in between to "produce" your pharaceuticals. The tricky part is that every type of machine has a defined input point and a defined output point, which means that if you have to put like 5 of them behind each other, you will invariably end up either in a circle or in a really bad design.Solving this is, basically, the game.Is it still fun? Surprisingly, yes it is. The graphics is cute enough to make it fun to watch that machine do its magic, and the liberty you have to make decisions is just enough to give you something to ponder. Should you scrap that low profit production line and hope that you can squeeze in the much larger one that gets you better profit? Do you have room to use three cheaper machines than one expensive one? Should you hire more scientists to make production cheaper in the long run, even though they're expensive to hire and maintain? Is it good enough to warrant the price tag? I'd say yes, but I wouldn't pay more than that.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: December 1, 2016
												UPDATED REVIEW:I initially gave this game a negative review due to the incredible difficulty. There is an extreme learning curve here, at least for me. It took me a solid 10 hours of gameplay before I finally figured out how to complete even the 2nd beginner scenario. I will admit that I rage-quit several different times before finally getting the hang of it. Therefore, if you have little to no patience (like me), beware. This isn't the best game ever made, but it also isn't the worst. It isn't your typical "tycoon" game, as it requires a LOT more thought and strategy. I still wish there was a difficulty slider so wimpy me could make it a bit easier, but I would have to say that I have enjoyed my time playing. I sitll dislike that luck determines what ingredients you start off with, but I suppose this allows for a bit of replayability as no two scenarios are ever quite the same. All in all, I would recommend this game, but only on sale. The standard price seems a bit steep for what this game has to offer.NOTE: I do not own the DLC, so I can't provide any opinion on that. ORIGINAL REVIEW BELOW:What a shame... I really thought I would love this game. I've always been a sucker for tycoon/management games.Alas, this game is rage-inducingly difficult, and there is no difficulty setting, so you're stuck with what you have. Even more strangely, it seems that each new game is randomized so there is a bit of a luck factor involved. I can't even finish the 2nd "begiinner" mission (after three tries) without failing and, therefore, rage-quitting. I wonder how I would do on the advanced missions? :DTutorial is quite useless and does little to help you complete the scenarios. My company is always bleeding money while the AI companies seemingly instantly turn into millionaires. So glad I got this as part of a bundle, because I probably won't be launching it again...Not recommended. I would not buy it again if I knew then what I know now. This game has brought me no enjoyment whatsoever.

												If one is looking for a pretty decent strategy simulation game then they have come to the right place. although the game is suppose to be a simulation, it really is not besides the fact that you have to moderate a budget, but it does not take away from the game in anyway. the premise of the game is to research machines, and ingredents and finally use both of these together to great a drug in which can can be sold for high value, easy enough... the game is not a complex one to play and is pretty straight forward once you have completed the tutorial. although there are opponents they do not really have anything to do with you as a player except annoy you with constant updates that they have created a new drug.. although they might be smarter in later difficulties as there are patents in the game and they may use them to prevent you from developing that legendary quality drug. the only big con about the game which is not something that could be avoided was that there is no strategy in the game. its the same build set up the entire game. mass produce as many low quality drugs untill you have found catalysts and have the machines to create the next lvl tier drug then mass produce those and repeat till there is not any high lvl drugs to mass produce. money is super easy to keep flowing in so its easy to have lots of scientists and researchs to generate points to make things cheaper to operate. besides this small con the game is lots of fun if you want to just relax and play a game that is not a FPS or RTS becuase the building layouts are different in each scenario which makes it harder to set up that lane of 50 plus pieces of equipment to make the highest end tier drugs.

												Really quite a fun production-line game. number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: May 14, 2016
												I've had Big Pharma for a while now; I bought it when it wasn't on steam (A few months before the release) and have gotten a pretty solid idea on the game.Graphics: Simple 2nd Dimensional, isometric camera view. All the machines have nice animations, and the customization of your building, albeit basic with flooring and wall paper, add a bit of hominess and individuality to your lines.Sound: Not much to say. The music is nice and the sound effects are good, but far from breaking any records. Gameplay: Big Pharma is a building game, a puzzle game, and a business management game. You pick "play" and you are presented with a wide varity of missions. These range from "produce X amount of treatment for X" to "Make a profit of X dollars." What is great is that you are able to approach this however you want; the game doesn't force you to follow specific paths. You get to build whatever manufacturing lines you'd like to produce medications. It gives a feeling of freedom, compared to other games where they hold your hand and demand you do things in a certain order, and more or less penalize you for differentiating. Each effect requires a bevy of actions first. To get treatment for X, first you must set the concentration to the right values with machines like the evaporator and ioniser. You may need to combine it with a catalyst effect- Which comes with other symptoms too, so you have to figure out what to do with the biproduct too. Along with keeping a functioning line running, you need to keep a mind for space conservation- each exspansion of your building takes money, and they aren't too roomy. Along with making sure your lines work and you have enough space, you need to keep an eye on your competitors; developed a wondercure for a very exspensive symptom? Soon, the AI competitors will rush to roll out those medications and steal some of your profits. Multi-tasking is a critical part of the game, and if you will have a bad time if you're only good at focusing one thing at a time. Another great feature is the hands-on tutorial. It lays down the foundation you need to understand the game and get a business running, but is entirely skippable if you chose.Overall, Big Pharma is a great game if you're into the business management economic simulator genre of games.

content:
Posted: February 18, 2016
												Big Pharma scratches two itches for me - puzzle solving and management, and has become a very addictive game.* Puzzle: Putting together the production lines effectively is a fun challenge that makes me think of SpaceChem, TIS-1000, and the like, but is quite abit easier. However, it also ties into the management size - can you make the drugs without them turning a loss instead of a profit? And do you let side-effects in to save money?* Management: Balancing the books, making profit from the drugs, and balancing research and exploration for new ingredients.The developer also seems to be continuing to support the game, having released an update recently to make the UI alittle better, and balance the game more.In short, I don't think it'll be everyone's cup of tea, but for me, its been grand and fun.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: March 12, 2016
												Greetings.I don't specialize in writing reviews, I don't have that many hours in, so it's just a human moment / perspective from a regular gamer. A little bit to describe my playstyle: it ranges from primitive shooters to sophisticated strategies, though I do have a thing for city building / production line management games (starts with Caesar III, then onto Anno and Zeus/Pharaoh/Caesar IV, Simcity, Skylines, etc).What do I have to say about the game? It's extremely catchy. System requirements are low, price's not that high (especially if you manage to grab it during a sale like I did); the game really does remind you of Theme Hospital quite a bit. Hell, when I first saw it in my "featured" tab, I thought this was a remake of the series. You know, the kind when you can't exactly sell a game under its old name due to some legal issues, so this potentially looked like an Indie rework of some Theme Hospital fans. The similarity ends right there, Big Pharma has way more depth to it. I'm just going through the first stage of the tutorial but I can already see a lot of -interesting- complexities. Having said that, the game is really easy to learn. It's not a Hearts of Iron or Victoria by Paradox that you'll spend two weeks learning with constant hit-n'-miss play sessions resulting in frustration before you understand what every little button does and every tiny switch stands for.All in all, Big Pharma is exactly defined by its tags. An indie (the dev seems to respond in the hub), puzzle (gets you thinking, that's a check for a fact), strategy-management (Theme Hospital- / Tycoon Deluxe-style) with a theme that makes sense (simulation).Let's see if it manages to keep me busy long enough, I'll edit it then. <:

content:
Posted: February 20, 2016
												I played this game quite a bit in pre-Steam alpha - I recommend this game only to those who enjoy puzzle games, I'd say it's worth it if you can get it on sale for 10 bucks or less. If you are looking for a tycoon/management game, this is not it.------I was originally intrigued because it reminded me a bit of Theme Hospital, which - like most Bullfrog games, I loved - but this doesn't play like a tycoon game, or a management game. It's more of a puzzle game. Think Tetris where you have to research the different pieces. This game cries out for a sandbox mode... where you can build a room, build an import, layout your machinery, then build an export - use the funds to research/innovate/explore etc - enlarge your factory, add more production lines, make more money, stay ahead of the competition. Instead you get numerous scenarios in which you have to gain an arbitrary amount of money and/or create a specific type of medicine by a certain date and/or before the competiton. The game itself is that you fit your production line into a predetermined amount of space. The ingredients must be researched and require various amounts of machines (which must also be researched) to get them into medically effective states. Your work out the logistics to make it all fit. Rinse, repeat. Personally, I dislike scenario games like this; any game where I'm asked to spend time building something only to leave it all behind and start again from scratch level after level, wears thin on me rather quickly.That said, the game is extremely well made in terms of quality, the UI has been streamlined and overall it's very solid. This dev knows what they're doing, and I look forward to more of their work.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: February 25, 2016
												Big Pharma is a great little game in which you get to play as the big pharmaceutical companies, create drugs, sell them and build up reputation.The game is in essens a puzzle game with some light management thrown in for good measure. Most of the gameplay is creating drug chains that optimizes drugs (for profit or usefulness) and then to sell them. Which is really a really satisfying puzzle game. All of the machines that create drugs have a different shape and size and in order to fit them all in you either need to plan out what you'll need ahead of time, because moving production lines after they are completed is really difficult, alternatively you can buy smaller more effective machines, however those will crank up the production cost for the drug, directly affecting your bottom line.The game is great in that you can create really weird drugs that may or may not actually work, but after all it's all about making money and not drugs right? You will need to decide wheater you value space efficiency vs price, what research should you prioretize. All the while trying to stay ahead of the competition which have just patented your new drug formula rendering the giganormous production line you just created, worthless...It's a great little zen game where once in a while you sit back and just wait for your drugs' ratings go up or down, accumulate money etc. Contemplating weather or not it's the right time to expand, what you should expand into, is it worth optimizing that one cure so that its drug rating goes up...There's almost always something to do, at least in the beginning and then the game zens out after a while.One bad thing about the game however is that when you get to a sort of "critical mass" you basically cannot lose, except  for deadlines. There's not really too many challenges after the initial ones, because when you manage to get enough drugs to sell, you will start making tons of money and the game really turns into a fine tuning game. I'm not saying it isn't  fun at that point, but it really doesn't require as much baby sitting.On the other hand that might be exactly what you're looking for as you can then sit and maybe catch up on a series, Youtube etc.All in all, it's a nice little game, especially if you can get it in a sale, great if you need something to stimulate that gamer part of the brain as you catch up on videos or whatever. I for one can't just sit and do one thing at a time, so this is a great game for me. :)

content:
Posted: September 26, 2016
 DISCLAIMER: This is a first impressions review, and NOT a full review, if you want a full review, then please read better reviews then mine Big Pharma is a game developed by Twice Circled and published by Positech Games, the same people behind Gratuitous Space Battles' series, Gratuitous Tank Battles and the Democracy seriesBig Pharma throws you into the medicinal making business where you run a pharmacuetical company distributing drugs that help people whilst also making big green dollar bills. The game is both a management simulation game and also surprisingly a bit of a puzzle gameTo create a drug you first have to find the suitable ingredients, each ingredient comes with a cure, a side effect and sometimes a booster (these are usually found in other ingredients and not the same one). Through that you then can make you're drug by processing it through machinery that can mix and match to evenly balance both the cure and the side effectsThe game is fun yet challenging at the same time, and with the constant upgrades you can make more and more drugs which then can be sold on the marketHowever, the game can get repetitive and some points and it does have a steep learning curve to master the game which can put some people off, you don't have to play it the correct way (which is what free build offers you), however, it is interesting to play how the game wants you to playBig Pharma is not for everyone, me personally, I enjoy it when I play it in short bursts, however, the game is not for everyone... RECOMMENDED :)
