Posted: September 26, 2016
												Theme Hospital's and Tetris' illegitimate love child a decade later.Mildy amusing at first, though the tutorial on mixing ingredients needs improving to make things clearer but once you've figured that out, how to remove side effects and how to control the shaker... that's it!There's not really anything more to the game after that, all further research and exploration is really just enhancements to your profit margin. If it's on sale for €5-10 it may be worth a try if you liked the Theme Park/Theme Hospital games, if it's full price then give it a miss.If you want this sort of game I'd suggest checking out Capitalism II instead, sure the graphics might be lacking but there's a lot more to the actual game itself.As for the reference to Tetris above that's what trying to squeeze in as many product lines as possible into each building is like.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: September 29, 2016
												Big Pharma's an enjoyable enough game during the first few hours of play, but after you get the rythm down, it quickly loses its appeal. You spend the better part of the game just perfecting formulas for your meds and adjusting sale percentages by one or two percent on your arsenal of pills or creams. There isnt a whole lot of depth that I've seen, even the tech tree is pretty lack luster and offers you a total of maybe ten or twelve buildings total for your factory. Seriously, this game is kinda like adjusting the ph on your pool while watching your stocks bounce around on your phone.It's pretty fun though for a little while though, and some of the animations are neat, but once you scratch beyond the surface, this game lacks personality and depth. There's no real story and every game plays out pretty much the same way (maybe to add authenticity to the real world big pharma). If you're new to these sort of management/production games, this might not be a bad title for you.Unfortunately, I enjoy a bit more challenge and diversity in my logistic games. I'd been watching this one for a while and got it on sale for just under $9 and honestly I feel that was a fair price for what I got. If you're like me and play a lot of these types of games, I encourage you to check out 'Factorio' or even 'Off World Trading Company' instead.

content:
Posted: August 31, 2015
												Big Pharma is a fantastic management and simulation game. It's an usual subject to be managing, but now that I've played the game I'm surprised that it took this long for someone to think of it!The game is a great balance of logic puzzle (in the form of making profitable drugs), business (deciding when to expand, when to invest, when to do nothing), and simulation of the pharmaceutical industry. I played this when it was first released in beta and it is a LOT better since that point, so if you read about the previous releases and weren't sure I'd suggest looking at a more recent review before deciding to buy. It's a great example of an early access game doing what you would hope: improving in the run up to release and being a better product when it gets there.Positech has a great history of supporting and developing games post-release, and I look forward to playing this game for a long time to come with more and better things to do in it.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: October 2, 2016
												Big Pharma could be characterized as a procedural logic puzzle game with several random-ish elements.But that sounded a bit boring, so I'd rather call it a "living puzzle".Basically you got your factory gadgets, which need to face certain directions, and you connect them to each other with conveyor belts. Then you input drug ingredients from wall sockets and upgrade them along the production line. You can rotate the gadgets, but not mirror them. After you decide your production line is long enough and your drug is done, it must be processed into a pill, a cream etc. and sent back into a wall socket - then you can begin selling it!It's not a simple as it sounds, in fact I think this game is quite challenging, at least with the DLC add-on. Some people said that the base game is a bit easy, but I only played with the DLC. Every factory gadget has a processing cost when stuff moves through it. So you have to ensure your drug is cheap to make by optimizing the amount of gadgets. You can make your drug stronger and boost your sales by getting rid of side-effects or adding positive effects and boosters from other ingredients, but there are many specific logical rules in place which ensure that you will mostly have a hard time doing so.After playing a while I have to say I like this game. Somehow it balances the line between being both addictive and frustrating at the same time. The game is quite well made and balanced gameplay-wise, and I've yet to see any bugs in the game which is also a very good sign.

												If one is looking for a pretty decent strategy simulation game then they have come to the right place. although the game is suppose to be a simulation, it really is not besides the fact that you have to moderate a budget, but it does not take away from the game in anyway. the premise of the game is to research machines, and ingredents and finally use both of these together to great a drug in which can can be sold for high value, easy enough... the game is not a complex one to play and is pretty straight forward once you have completed the tutorial. although there are opponents they do not really have anything to do with you as a player except annoy you with constant updates that they have created a new drug.. although they might be smarter in later difficulties as there are patents in the game and they may use them to prevent you from developing that legendary quality drug. the only big con about the game which is not something that could be avoided was that there is no strategy in the game. its the same build set up the entire game. mass produce as many low quality drugs untill you have found catalysts and have the machines to create the next lvl tier drug then mass produce those and repeat till there is not any high lvl drugs to mass produce. money is super easy to keep flowing in so its easy to have lots of scientists and researchs to generate points to make things cheaper to operate. besides this small con the game is lots of fun if you want to just relax and play a game that is not a FPS or RTS becuase the building layouts are different in each scenario which makes it harder to set up that lane of 50 plus pieces of equipment to make the highest end tier drugs.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: November 23, 2016
												Purchased the DLC (M&M), and played recently. I nominated the game for 2016 Steam Award "WHOA, DUDE", because I feel every cent spent on the game has turned into gold in every aspect. I enjoyed it a lot (150 hours so far)! It is a rare game, that is not underdeveloped, but polished. It has wide range of challenge from simple to really hard one, good sense of events, the game is updated and rebalanced, and even the DLC is adding in the manner of these values. Maybe I overhype, but this is incredible, and never seen this level of care for a game! Anyone, who likes tycoon type of games, this is a musthave. It can be played easy, it can be played complicated...really up to you. Both ways, you get unbent experience. This game is a high class standard, with no 50 EUR pricetag on it.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: December 2, 2016
												Recently gotten within a bundle with other games, this is a nice little puzzle/logic game.The management part is minimal as all that is required is for you to complete certain objectives within a certain time frame while staying afloat with your income. Expenses comes from research, exploration, ingredients and process cost.The challenge mostly come for choosing which priority comes first as well as managing the limited space correctly.The only major Con I have with the game, is the fact that certain objectives requires the production of medecines that requires catalyst (mixing the attributes of a different ingredient), however as ingredients are generated at random at the beginning of each game, it often happens that the needed catalyst is not even available at all, thus forcing you to start over sometime half an hour in.That annoyance aside, very fun little game overall. I'd put the correct entry price at 10$ or less thought.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: November 12, 2016
												This is a puzzle/logistics game that dives into the economy/politics side of drug companies.  There are various challenges to complete, with different tiers of success, ensuring you will come back to previous challenges with more experience and a better outcome.  Some examples of challenges include, deliver 200 units of hair loss product (requiring desert research and follow-up exploration and an end-game atomic sequencer) before a set amount of time, produce 6 products with a B+ rating (you can make a few extra bucks if you don't process out side-effects, but this challenge requires you to find profitable and sustainable drugs without using questionable business practices), and make as much money as possible using patents, putting out as much product with as little work as possible, and undercutting the AI businesses as much as possible!This game's business side is a little light, but is expanded on in the very affordable DLC that add new layers to the game.  I would recommend getting the DLC, but only after you try the base game.  It isn't everyone's cup of tea, but it sure is mine!

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: April 13
												This is probably one of my favorite games ever.I have a soft spot for this type of game: automation, managment, logic, conveyor belts!!! It's like Theme Hospital meets Factorio, and I've lost a lot of time to this wonderful hybrid.While the actual mechanics of the game might seem complicated, and it would appear to be that it's one of those games that you have to play for hours until you really get the hang of it, it's not like that at all! Big Pharma has a brilliantly intuitive tutorial, a clean while still visually (and audially) interesting aesthetic, and an inviting, trance-like feel to it that will likely make me forget that I even have exams to study for – but in a good way!Overall, I'd definitely give this a try, and I think it's well worth the price.

content:
Posted: April 23
												for me, it's not worth it. it's a fine game, don't get me wrong, but even after being explained the mechanics by the hard-to-understand tutorial text, and playing the game for 8 hours i still struggle every time i play. it's also hard to get a sense of what's going on in-game just by looking, and after a while all the conveyor belts and ionizers just start to bleed into this gross off-white color, and my brain cells start dying due to overexertion. i play games that are fun to play (as most people do), and big pharma is just based off of maximizing profit while minimizing space and managing time, and i thought i would like it as i did with other management games, but this is just... bad. and i have nowhere near enough time as i would need to get good at this game, and there just isn't any real potential for this game after you beat all the "levels" or whatever. it's pretty heinous.
